title: About and Motivation
body:
I created this website because I thought there might be a need for an even simpler way to find things to do locally than what's already published to the web. Plus I didn't want to have to login to social media every time to find things. I had some ideas and put them to task. What came out was a local guides library to find events and places of interest, then and group notable acitivies from the area. I popped in some discovery features like search and tagging and was happy with the result. Now I'm sharing it with you. I hope you find it helpful.

I'm open to feedback and/or ideas, please send them to jack@thingshappening.com.

Meet the Authors

Viki Vaillancourt is an avid explorer of Chattanooga’s outdoors and history, with a keen eye for uncovering hidden gems in the area. As a contributing writer to the website, Viki brings her passion for the city’s natural beauty and rich past to life in her articles. Her 20 years in Chattanooga have given her plenty of time to discover those off-the-beaten-path spots, and she loves sharing them with others in a warm, engaging way. Whether it's a quiet trail or a piece of Chattanooga's history, Viki is always on the lookout for something new to share.
Jack Burnham is your go-to guide for all things Chattanooga. After calling the city home for seven years, he's spent countless hours exploring its trails, uncovering hidden gems, and delving into the rich history that makes Chattanooga so unique. With a deep love for the outdoors and a knack for finding those off-the-beaten-path spots, Jack shares his discoveries with a laid-back, friendly style that makes every adventure feel like exploring with an old friend.

Guides


100 Things to Do in Chattanooga Before You Die
Author: Alexi Ruth Engesath
Published Year: 2018
Overview: If you're looking to make the most out of your time here in Chattanooga, check out "100 Things to Do in Chattanooga Before You Die" by Alexi Ruth Engesath. The book is full of must-see spots and hidden gems that make Chattanooga such a amazing place. You'll find everything from epic outdoor adventures and awesome dining spots to cultural attractions and fun activities for the family. The book is easy to navigate, with detailed descriptions and helpful tips for each activity.


Five-Star Trails: Chattanooga: 40 Spectacular Hikes in and Around the Scenic City
Author: Johnny Molloy
Published Year: 2020
Overview: Written for both novice and experienced hikers, the book highlights the diverse natural beauty of the region with trails featuring stunning views, waterfalls, and historical sites. Each hike comes with a comprehensive description, including trail length, difficulty level, estimated hiking time, and elevation changes. The guide also provides valuable local insights, including the best seasons to hike and practical tips for preparation.

Key features of the book:
1. Trail variety with easy walks to challenging hikes.
2. Detailed descriptions with essential trail information.
3. Comprehensive maps and precise directions.
4. Local insights and hiking tips.
5. Photography capturing the region's beauty. Accessibility information for different needs.

Chattanooga Landmarks: Exploring the History of the Scenic City
Author: Jennifer Crutchfield
Published Year: 2010
Overview: This book dives into the rich history of Chattanooga, highlighting key landmarks that have shaped the city. It’s packed with interesting stories and details about places like Lookout Mountain, the Tennessee River, and historic downtown spots. Each landmark is brought to life with engaging narratives and beautiful photos. If you're curious about the city’s past, this book is a great guide to understanding what makes Chattanooga so special.



History



Hidden History of Chattanooga
Author: Alexandra Walker Clark
Published Year: 2008
Overview: Curious about the lesser-known stories of Chattanooga? You might want to check out this book. It uncovers all the fascinating, hidden tales that you won’t find in the usual history books. It’s got intriguing stories about secret tunnels, forgotten events, and unique characters that have shaped the city. Each chapter reveals a new piece of Chattanooga’s past that’s both surprising and fascinating.


Haunted Chattanooga
Author: Jessica Penot, Amy Petulla
Published Year: 2010
Overview: This book explores Chattanooga's most haunted locations, including the ghost of the Delta Queen, the spectral porter at Terminal Station, and the restless spirits in the city's underground tunnels. Through detailed accounts and historical context, the authors reveal the supernatural tales that continue to haunt the Scenic City. This book is part of the Haunted America series and combines local folklore, history, and spine-chilling ghost stories.


Images of America: Chattanooga
Author: Jerry R. Desmond
Published Year: 1996
Overview: Chattanooga (Images of America)gives a visual and historical journey through Chattanooga's transformation from a small river landing (Ross's Landing) to a significant industrial center. This book highlights pivotal moments, such as the arrival of the Western and Atlantic Railroad in 1849 and key Civil War battles like Chickamauga, Lookout Mountain, and Missionary Ridge in 1863.



Chattanooga (Then & Now: Tennessee)
Author: Rob Clifton
Published Year: 2006
Overview: Rob Clifton brings you on a journey through the city's history. This book pairs historical photographs with contemporary images, revealing the changes in Chattanooga's landmarks, streets, and neighborhoods. Clifton’s commentary provides context, illustrating how the city has evolved while preserving its heritage. This visual narrative is a valuable resource for anyone interested in Chattanooga's past and present, offering a unique perspective on the city's transformation over the years. Explore the rich history and ongoing development of Chattanooga in this compelling photographic collection.


Local Authors

Ishmael Reed   Born in Chattanooga, Tennessee, Ishmael Reed is a prolific American author, poet, essayist, and educator. Reed's work often explores African American culture and history, blending elements of surrealism, folklore, and mythology.

His novel "Mumbo Jumbo" (1972) is considered a masterpiece, featuring a satirical and nonlinear narrative that delves into African American culture and the influence of Western civilization. Other notable novels include "The Last Days of Louisiana Red" (1974) and "Flight to Canada" (1976), a parody of slave narratives and historical novels.

Reed has also published volumes of poetry, such as "Conjure: Selected Poems, 1963-1970". He has received numerous awards, including a MacArthur Fellowship in 1998 and the American Book Award for Lifetime Achievement. Reed has taught at various institutions, including the University of California, Berkeley.

Cherie Priest   Earned a Master’s degree in Rhetoric and Professional Writing from the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga. Her debut novel, "Four and Twenty Blackbirds" (2005) marked the beginning of her Eden Moore series, which blends Southern Gothic and supernatural elements.

She gained wider recognition for her steampunk series, "The Clockwork Century," beginning with "Boneshaker" (2009). The novel is set in an alternate history Seattle during the Civil War and involves zombies, airships, and adventure. The series includes several other novels, such as "Dreadnought" and "Ganymede.". You can check out her other works here

The Girl Who Struck Out Babe Ruth
Author: Jean L. S. Patrick
Published Year: 2000
Chattanooga Relation: On April 1, 1931, 17-year-old Jackie Mitchell struck out Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig during a postponed exhibition game in Chattanooga after being brought in by Lookouts manager Bert Niehoff.
Overview: In "The Girl Who Struck Out Babe Ruth," a fascinating blend of history and inspiration, meet Jackie Mitchell, a determined 17-year-old pitcher in the 1930s. Defying the odds and societal norms, Jackie finds herself on the mound facing the legendary Babe Ruth. With grit and an unyielding spirit, she delivers a pitch that would forever etch her name in baseball history.


Flesh and Bone
Author: Jefferson Bass
Published Year: 2009
Chattanooga Relation: Part of the Body Farm series, which centers around Dr. Bill Brockton, a forensic anthropologist. While the series is primarily set in Tennessee, "Flesh and Bone" includes significant scenes and connections to Chattanooga.
Overview: Thriller that takes you on a ride through the world of forensic anthropology. Dr. Bill Brockton, is thrown into a particularly difficult case when a woman's body is found in an art park, posed like a statue. The twist? Brockton himself becomes a suspect in the murder..


Don't Cry
Author: Beverly Barton
Published Year: 2016
Chattanooga Relation: Fiction Romantic suspense novel set in Chattanooga.
Overview: This romantic suspense novel follows a serial killer investigation, with FBI agent J.D. Cass and psychologist Audrey Sherrod working together to uncover the truth. The Chattanooga setting provides a rich backdrop for the unfolding mystery and drama.


Extended Stay
Author: Bradley Cannon
Published Year: 2014
Chattanooga Relation: Fiction novel set in Chattanooga. In "Extended Stay" by Bradley Cannon, weary traveler Ethan checks into a Chattanooga hotel, uncovering its sinister secrets and confronting ghostly occurrences and mysterious disappearances in a gripping thriller..
Overview: In "Extended Stay" by Bradley Cannon, a gripping thriller unfolds in the eerie corridors of a secluded hotel in Chattanooga. When weary traveler Ethan checks in, he anticipates a brief respite from his troubles, but the hotel's sinister secrets soon ensnare him. As he delves deeper into the mysterious disappearances and ghostly occurrences haunting the premises, Ethan must confront his darkest fears and unravel the hotel's chilling past. With each twist and turn, Cannon masterfully builds suspense, making "Extended Stay" a heart-pounding read that will keep you on the edge of your seat until the final, shocking revelation.


Bookstores

**The Book & Cover**   A cozy new addition to Chattanooga’s bookstore scene, The Book & Cover offers a selection of new books with a focus on contemporary fiction and children’s literature. They also have a charming café inside. **McKay's Books**   A local favorite, McKay's is a large used bookstore with a vast selection of books, movies, music, and more. It’s a treasure trove for those seeking hidden gems. **Star Line Books**   Located in the heart of downtown Chattanooga, Star Line Books offers a thoughtfully curated selection of books across various genres. They regularly host author events, book clubs, and other engaging literary gatherings. **Winder Binder**   This unique bookstore and art gallery in Chattanooga specializes in used and rare books, as well as local art and music. It’s a must-visit for book lovers and art enthusiasts alike.

Nostalgic Nuances: Black and White Views of an Antique Store
Chattanooga and its surrounding areas are a top destination for antique enthusiasts, with a variety of stores that appeal to both seasoned collectors and casual browsers. The region offers an impressive selection of antique shops, each with its own distinct character and a range of unique finds. Whether you're drawn to large antique malls with numerous vendors or prefer the cozy atmosphere of smaller, family-run shops, Chattanooga's antique scene has something for everyone. You'll find everything from rare collectibles and historical artifacts to unique home decor pieces that can add character to any space. For those who enjoy the thrill of discovery, Chattanooga offers an experience where every visit can lead to finding something special. Here's a guide to some of the best antique stores in the area, each offering its own collection of treasures.

1.  Dirty Jane's

Dirty Jane's Antiques, located at 1910 Dayton Blvd, Chattanooga, TN 37415, is a beloved destination for antique enthusiasts. Spanning a massive 24,000 square feet, the store houses over 100 vendors offering an eclectic mix of vintage, quirky, beautiful, and historical items. Visitors can find a diverse range of antiques including furniture, records, jewelry, comics, books, clothing, blankets, art, and more​​.

Go Treasure Hunting For:
  • Vintage wicker bassinets
  • Industrial wood furniture
  • Decorative plates
  • Crystal balls
  • Antique store displays and fixtures from the 1940s and ‘50s

    • One customer, Alexis Harris, praised the store as "THE BEST antique store in all of the greater Chattanooga area!!" She highlighted the store's eclectic array of vintage finds and friendly staff, rating it a "15/10 antique store"​. Another reviewer, Gretchen Renlund, described it as "a fantastic place to spend some time exploring and shopping for some amazingly unique finds," noting the unmatched customer service and selection​. Jessica Sitton Angela mentioned it as her favorite shop during an antique weekend in Chattanooga, appreciating the fun booths and good variety of items​.

    Operating Hours: Tuesday to Saturday: 10 AM - 6 PM Sunday: 12 PM - 6 PM Closed on Mondays​.

The store's unique finds and the friendly, knowledgeable staff make it a must-visit for antique lovers in the Chattanooga area​. For more information, you can visit their website.

title: Chattanooga Outdoors: 10 Caves To Explore Near Chattanooga
body:
Water flowing through a narrow cave passage
Chattanooga's caves offer a unique glimpse into the region's natural beauty and geological history. By visiting these caves, you not only experience breathtaking formations and fascinating underground landscapes but also support the conservation efforts that preserve these natural treasures for future generations. Plan your visit today and discover the hidden wonders beneath Chattanooga's surface.

Chattanooga's subterranean marvels provide an extraordinary opportunity to explore the intricate and diverse world that lies beneath our feet. Each cave tells a story of millions of years of geological processes, showcasing a stunning array of formations such as stalactites, stalagmites, flowstone, and underground lakes. These natural wonders are not only visually captivating but also scientifically significant, offering insights into the region's geological past and the forces that have shaped its present landscape.

Chattanooga and its surrounding areas offer an array of stunning caves to explore, catering to both casual visitors and adventurous spelunkers. Here is a guide to some of the must-visit caves in the region, complete with logistical details and what to expect.

1.  Raccoon Mountain Caverns

Raccoon Mountain Caverns, located at 319 West Hills Dr, Chattanooga, TN 37419, is a vast cave system featuring over 5.5 miles of explored passageways. The caverns are known for their high level of active speleothem growth, including stalactites, stalagmites, flowstone, rimstone pools, draperies, columns, natural bridges, and rare shield formations​​.

The caverns are situated in a limestone and sandstone formation typical of the Cumberland Plateau. The cave system includes various formations created by the slow deposition of minerals from dripping water over thousands of years. The presence of fossils and unique wildlife, such as the Crystal Caverns Cave Spider, adds to the geological significance of the site​​.

Discovered in 1929, Raccoon Mountain Caverns has a rich history of exploration. Initially known as Tennessee Caverns, the site has undergone several name changes, eventually becoming Raccoon Mountain Caverns in the late 1970s. The cave was first opened to the public in the 1930s, with tours focused on the Crystal Palace Room. Further exploration in the 1950s and 1970s expanded the known passageways and introduced more adventurous spelunking tours​​.

Visitors can choose between the Crystal Palace Walking Tour and the Wild Cave Expeditions. The Crystal Palace Tour is a 45-55 minute guided tour through the first quarter mile of the cave, featuring well-lit pathways and steps. For a more adventurous experience, the Wild Cave Expeditions take visitors to the undeveloped sections of the cave, requiring physical exertion and crawling through tight spaces​​.

The Crystal Palace Walking Tour is suitable for all ages and experience levels, while the Wild Cave Expeditions are recommended for those with a higher fitness level and a spirit for adventure. Crowds can vary, with weekends and holidays being the busiest times. It is advisable to book tours in advance, especially for the Wild Cave Expeditions​​.

Raccoon Mountain Caverns is open year-round, with tours running daily from 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM. The best times to visit are during weekdays and early mornings to avoid the crowds. The constant temperature inside the cave is around 58 degrees Fahrenheit, making it a comfortable visit regardless of the season​​.

One visitor shared, "The Crystal Palace Tour was fascinating, with so many beautiful formations to see. Our guide was knowledgeable and made the experience enjoyable." Another reviewer mentioned, "The Wild Cave Expedition was an unforgettable adventure. Crawling through tight spaces and seeing parts of the cave that few get to see was thrilling"​​.

Raccoon Mountain Caverns offers a unique and educational experience for visitors of all ages. Whether you are interested in a leisurely walk through illuminated pathways or an adventurous spelunking expedition, the caverns provide an unforgettable journey into the underground world. For more information, you can visit the official website.

2.  Ruby Falls

Ruby Falls, located at 1720 South Scenic Highway, Chattanooga, TN 37409, is the tallest and deepest underground waterfall open to the public in the United States. Discovered by Leo Lambert in 1928, the waterfall descends 145 feet within Lookout Mountain and is part of the extensive Lookout Mountain Caverns​​.

The caverns are carved out of limestone, featuring a variety of formations such as stalactites, stalagmites, columns, and draperies formed over millions of years. The highlight of the tour is Ruby Falls, a stunning waterfall illuminated to showcase its natural beauty​​.

Ruby Falls was accidentally discovered when Leo Lambert and his team were drilling to reopen the Lookout Mountain Cave. The falls were named after Lambert's wife, Ruby, and opened to the public in 1929. The site has since become a major tourist attraction, drawing visitors from all over the world​​.

Visitors can choose from several guided tours, including the Classic Waterfall Tour, Lantern Tour, and Extended Cavern Experience. The tours typically last between 1 to 2 hours, guiding visitors through well-lit pathways and showcasing the unique geological formations. The temperature inside the cave is a constant 60 degrees Fahrenheit, making it a comfortable visit year-round​​.

Ruby Falls is a popular attraction and can get crowded, especially on weekends and holidays. It is recommended to book tickets in advance online to ensure availability. The tours are suitable for all ages and experience levels, although some sections of the cave can be narrow and may require moderate physical exertion​​.

The best times to visit Ruby Falls are during weekdays and early mornings to avoid the largest crowds. The cave is open daily from 8:00 AM to 8:00 PM​​.

One visitor shared, "The tour was informative and the waterfall is absolutely breathtaking. A must-see when visiting Chattanooga." Another reviewer mentioned, "Our guide was fantastic, and the cave formations are amazing. The highlight was definitely the illuminated waterfall"​​.

Ruby Falls offers a unique and mesmerizing experience with its stunning underground waterfall and fascinating cave formations. It is a must-visit destination for anyone exploring Chattanooga. For more information, you can visit the official website.

3.  Nickajack Cave

Nickajack Cave, located near New Hope, TN, is a fascinating partially flooded cave rich in history and natural beauty. The cave, partially submerged due to the construction of the Nickajack Dam in 1967, is known for its large entrance which measures 140 feet wide and 50 feet high​​.

The cave is part of a limestone formation typical of the region and features several unique geological structures formed by the natural processes of erosion and water flow. The entrance of the cave is now partially submerged, creating an intriguing water feature that can be explored by boat​​.

Nickajack Cave has a rich history dating back to its use by Native American tribes, including the Chickamauga Cherokee. In the 1800s, the cave was mined for saltpeter, a key ingredient in gunpowder, particularly during the War of 1812 and the Civil War. The cave also gained notoriety when musician Johnny Cash visited it in 1967 during a low point in his life, finding spiritual renewal there​​.

Today, Nickajack Cave is a protected wildlife refuge, particularly known for its large colony of gray bats. Visitors can view the bats from an observation deck, especially during the summer evenings when thousands of bats emerge from the cave at dusk. Guided kayak tours are available, providing a unique perspective of the cave from the water​​.

The site is popular for wildlife viewing, especially during the bat emergence season. It is suitable for all experience levels, though the best experience is had by those comfortable with kayaking or canoeing. Crowds can vary, with summer weekends being the busiest​​.

The best times to visit Nickajack Cave are from late spring to early fall, particularly in the evenings to witness the bat emergence. Early mornings can also offer a quieter experience with fewer visitors​​.

One visitor shared, "Watching the bats emerge from Nickajack Cave at sunset was an unforgettable experience. The sight of thousands of bats against the evening sky was mesmerizing." Another reviewer mentioned, "Kayaking near the cave and seeing the bats was a unique and incredible adventure. Highly recommended for nature lovers"​​.

Nickajack Cave offers a unique blend of natural beauty and historical significance. It is a must-visit destination for those interested in geology, history, and wildlife. For more information, you can visit the official website.

4.  Cumberland Caverns

Cumberland Caverns, located at 1437 Cumberland Caverns Road, McMinnville, TN 37110, is the second longest cave in Tennessee and the twelfth longest cave in the United States. With over 32 miles of underground passageways, it offers a diverse and extensive caving experience​​.

Formed in Mississippian Monteagle Limestone, the cave system features an array of geological formations, including stalagmites, stalactites, flowstone, helictites, cave pearls, botryoidal coral, and gypsum flowers. The cave also houses beautiful underground waterfalls and gleaming pools​​.

Discovered in 1810 by Aaron Higginbotham, the cave was initially known as Higgenbotham Cave. It was later named Cumberland Caverns and opened to the public on July 4, 1956. The cave has been a significant source of saltpeter and has a rich history linked to both the War of 1812 and the Civil War​​.

Cumberland Caverns offers a range of tours suitable for different experience levels. These include the Crystal Palace Walking Tour, which is ideal for beginners, and more adventurous spelunking tours such as the Higgenbotham’s Hollow and the Hall Crawl. The cave also hosts unique events like live music concerts in the Volcano Room, a natural auditorium within the cave​​.

The cave is a popular destination and can get crowded, especially on weekends and during special events. Booking tours in advance is recommended. The walking tours are suitable for all ages, while the adventure tours are recommended for those with a higher fitness level and a sense of adventure​​.

Cumberland Caverns is open daily from 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM, except on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve, and Christmas Day. The best times to visit are during weekdays and early mornings to avoid larger crowds​​.

One visitor shared, "Visiting Cumberland Caverns was an unforgettable experience. The formations are stunning, and the guide was very knowledgeable." Another reviewer mentioned, "The Volcano Room concert was amazing. The acoustics in the cave are incredible, and it was a unique experience to watch a show underground"​​.

Cumberland Caverns offers a unique blend of natural beauty and historical significance. It is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in geology, history, or adventure. For more information, you can visit the official website.
Cave ceiling adorned with stalagmites and stalactites

5.  The Lost Sea Adventure

The Lost Sea Adventure, located at 140 Lost Sea Road, Sweetwater, TN 37874, is home to America's largest underground lake, the Lost Sea. This impressive subterranean lake is part of the extensive Craighead Caverns system​​.

Craighead Caverns, formed in the Mississippian limestone, features a variety of unique geological formations, including stalactites, stalagmites, flowstone, and rare anthodites. The caverns are also home to an underground lake that stretches over four acres and reaches depths of over 140 feet​​.

The caverns have a rich history, serving as a shelter for Native Americans, a source of saltpeter for Confederate soldiers during the Civil War, and a site for moonshine production. The underground lake was discovered in 1905, and the site was developed into a tourist attraction in 1965​​.

Visitors to The Lost Sea Adventure can enjoy guided tours that include a 3/4-mile walk through the caverns and a boat ride on the underground lake. The tours last approximately 1 hour and 15 minutes and provide insights into the cave's history and geology. The tours are well-lit and safe, making them suitable for all ages​​.

The Lost Sea Adventure is a popular attraction, especially during weekends and holidays. It is recommended to visit during the off-season (September to May) for fewer crowds and shorter wait times. The tours are suitable for all experience levels, from families with children to seasoned adventurers​​.

The best times to visit are during weekdays and early mornings to avoid the largest crowds. The Lost Sea Adventure is open daily from 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM (extended hours in the summer). It is closed on Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day​​.

One visitor shared, "The tour was informative and the underground lake is stunning. The boat ride was a unique experience." Another reviewer mentioned, "A great family outing. The cave formations are fascinating, and our guide was excellent. Highly recommend the tour"​​.

The Lost Sea Adventure offers an unforgettable experience with its spectacular underground lake and fascinating cave formations. It is a must-visit destination for anyone exploring Tennessee. For more information, you can visit the official website.

6.  Ellison's Cave

Ellison's Cave is located in Walker County, Georgia, within the Crockford-Pigeon Mountain Wildlife Management Area. The cave is renowned for being one of the deepest caves in the United States, with a length of over 12 miles and a depth of 1,063 feet​​.

Ellison's Cave is a solutional cave formed in the limestone bedrock of the Appalachian Plateau. The cave features some of the deepest vertical pitches in the continental U.S., including the 586-foot Fantastic Pit and the 440-foot Incredible Pit. These pitches make the cave particularly notable for its vertical caving challenges​​.

The cave was first explored in the early 20th century and has since become a significant site for both scientific study and recreational caving. It was formed during the Paleozoic era, and the ongoing geological activity in the area continues to shape the cave's structure​​.

Ellison's Cave is not recommended for beginners due to its advanced and dangerous nature. It is primarily visited by experienced cavers who are equipped to handle its vertical drops and complex passageways. The cave's remote location and challenging terrain require visitors to be in excellent physical condition and well-prepared​​.

The cave is generally not crowded due to the advanced skills required to explore it. It is suitable only for experienced cavers with proper training and equipment. Casual visitors are advised against attempting to explore the cave due to its hazards​​.

The cave can be visited year-round, but the best times are during the cooler months to avoid the heat and to reduce the risk of dehydration and heat exhaustion. Always check weather conditions before planning a trip, as heavy rains can make the cave more dangerous​​.

One visitor shared, "Ellison's Cave offers a unique and challenging experience for advanced cavers. The vertical drops are exhilarating and require meticulous planning and execution." Another reviewer mentioned, "It's one of the most rewarding but dangerous caves I've explored. Not for the faint of heart, but an incredible adventure for those prepared"​​.

Ellison's Cave provides a thrilling experience for seasoned cavers with its deep pits and complex passages. It is a must-visit destination for those seeking adventure and challenge in the subterranean world. For more information, you can visit the official website.

7.  Tumbling Rock Cave

Tumbling Rock Cave, located at 3407 County Road 111, Fackler, AL 35746, is one of Alabama's most popular horizontal caves, offering more than six miles of passageways for exploration. The cave is managed by the Southeastern Cave Conservancy Inc. (SCCI) and is known for its impressive geological features​​.

Tumbling Rock Cave is a horizontal solutional cave formed in limestone. It boasts a variety of stunning formations, including stalactites, stalagmites, flowstone, and rimstone pools. Notable features include the 400-foot-tall Topless Dome and the Christmas Tree formation, a stalagmite decorated with lights during the holiday season​​.

The cave has a rich history, including use by Native Americans and as a source of saltpeter for gunpowder production during the Civil War. Evidence of historical mining operations can still be seen within the cave. It is named for a large boulder that appears precariously wedged between a ledge and the cave ceiling​​.

Tumbling Rock Cave offers a range of experiences suitable for both novice and experienced cavers. The main passage, known as the borehole, features a stream and leads to various rooms and formations. Guided tours and self-guided explorations are available, but a permit is required for entry​​.

The cave is popular among cavers, particularly on weekends. It is suitable for all experience levels, although the more challenging sections, like the climb to Topless Dome, require physical fitness and caving experience​​.

Tumbling Rock Cave can be visited year-round, with the cave maintaining a constant temperature of 58 degrees Fahrenheit. The best times to visit are during the cooler months to avoid heat and potential overcrowding​​.

One visitor shared, "Tumbling Rock is an incredible wild caving experience. There's so much to see and explore, and you could easily spend 6+ hours in this cave." Another reviewer mentioned, "The Topless Dome is the most impressive feature in the cave, with its breathtaking height and gentle waterfall"​​.

Tumbling Rock Cave offers a unique and thrilling experience with its extensive passages and fascinating geological features. It is a must-visit for anyone interested in caving or exploring the natural wonders of Alabama. For more information, you can visit the official website.
Hiker exploring the depths of the cave

8.  Russell Cave National Monument

Russell Cave National Monument, located at 3729 County Road 98, Bridgeport, AL 35740, is an important archaeological site that provides one of the most complete records of prehistoric cultures in the Southeastern United States. The cave was used by prehistoric peoples for over 10,000 years and offers a rich tapestry of artifacts and historical insights​​.

The cave is a limestone solutional cave, formed through the dissolution of limestone bedrock by acidic water. This process created the large, sheltering cavern that was used by prehistoric peoples. The cave contains a streambed formed by a natural spring, which provided a constant water source for its inhabitants​​.

Russell Cave was first used by Paleoindian peoples around 10,000 BCE. Over the millennia, it served as a seasonal shelter and hunting camp for various cultures, including the Archaic, Woodland, and Mississippian stages. Artifacts found in the cave include projectile points, pottery shards, basketry, fishhooks, and tools made from bone and chert. The cave's name comes from the Russell family, who owned the property in the 19th century​​.

Visitors to Russell Cave National Monument can explore the cave through ranger-led tours, which offer insights into the prehistoric cultures that once inhabited the site. The visitor center includes a museum with exhibits displaying artifacts recovered from the cave, as well as educational films about the early settlers of the region​​.

Russell Cave is generally not crowded, making it a pleasant experience for visitors of all ages and experience levels. The site is accessible for individuals with mobility issues, and the tours are suitable for families and children​​.

The best times to visit Russell Cave are during the spring and fall when the weather is mild. The monument is open daily from 8:00 AM to 4:30 PM, except on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day​​.

One visitor shared, "Russell Cave is a fascinating site with a rich history. The ranger-led tour was informative, and the artifacts in the museum are impressive." Another reviewer mentioned, "It's a hidden gem with a lot to offer. The cave and surrounding area are beautiful, and it's a great place to learn about prehistoric cultures"​​.

Russell Cave National Monument offers a unique glimpse into the past, showcasing the lives of prehistoric peoples who inhabited the Southeastern United States. For more information, you can visit the official website.

9.  Sauta Cave National Wildlife Refuge

Sauta Cave National Wildlife Refuge, located south of US Highway 72 between mile markers 130 and 131 in Scottsboro, AL 35769, is a 264-acre refuge known for its significant bat populations. Established in 1978 to protect endangered species, the refuge was originally named Blowing Wind Cave National Wildlife Refuge and later renamed in 1999​​.

Sauta Cave is a limestone solutional cave that serves as a crucial habitat for the federally endangered gray and Indiana bats. The cave features two large entrances on a hillside and is part of the Appalachian Plateau, characterized by rugged terrain and diverse plant life​​.

Historically, Sauta Cave was used by Native American tribes and later as a source of saltpeter during the Civil War. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service acquired the property to protect the endangered bat species and their habitat. It continues to serve as a significant summer roosting site for gray bats and a winter hibernaculum for both gray and Indiana bats​​.

The cave itself is gated and not open to the public to prevent disturbance to the bats. However, visitors can enjoy the refuge's hiking trails and wildlife observation opportunities. A notable event is the evening bat flight, where up to 400,000 bats emerge from the cave at dusk during the summer months. A viewing platform is available for this spectacular sight​​.

The refuge is generally not crowded, making it a peaceful destination for nature enthusiasts. It is suitable for all experience levels, although visitors should be prepared for outdoor conditions and bring appropriate gear for hiking and wildlife observation​​.

The best times to visit are during the summer months of June, July, and August to witness the bat emergence. Early morning and late evening visits are recommended to observe wildlife activity. The refuge is open year-round from dawn to dusk​​.

One visitor shared, "Watching the bats emerge at dusk was an incredible experience. The viewing platform provided a great vantage point." Another reviewer mentioned, "The trails are well-maintained and offer a peaceful hike through the forest. It's a great spot for nature lovers"​​.

Sauta Cave National Wildlife Refuge offers a unique opportunity to observe endangered bat species and enjoy outdoor recreation in a protected natural environment. For more information, you can visit the official website.

10.  Fricks Cave Preserve

Fricks Cave Preserve, located at 1510 Fricks Gap Rd, Chickamauga, GA 30707, is a highly protected cave known for its ecological and geological significance. The cave is managed by the Southeastern Cave Conservancy Inc. (SCCi) and is primarily noted for its large population of endangered gray bats and the presence of the rare Tennessee cave salamander​​.

Fricks Cave is a limestone solutional cave characterized by its impressive karst formations, including stalactites, stalagmites, and flowstone. The cave's ecosystem supports a variety of unique species, making it a critical habitat for conservation​​.

The cave has a rich history and has been used by humans for thousands of years. Artifacts found within the cave indicate its use by Native American tribes. The cave was later explored and documented by cavers and conservationists due to its ecological importance​​.

Access to Fricks Cave is highly restricted to protect the sensitive habitats within. The cave is typically closed to the public, with limited access granted through SCCi-sanctioned events, such as annual open houses where visitors can witness the evening bat flight. These events provide a rare opportunity to experience the cave's natural wonders without disturbing its delicate ecosystem​​.

Due to its restricted access, the cave does not experience large crowds. The limited access events are well-regulated to ensure minimal impact on the cave environment. These events are suitable for visitors of all experience levels, though participants should be prepared for outdoor conditions​​.

The best time to visit Fricks Cave is during the SCCi's open house events, typically held in late winter when the bat population is not present. This timing ensures the protection of the gray bats and provides an optimal experience for visitors​​.

One visitor shared, "The opportunity to see the gray bats in their natural habitat was incredible. The guides were knowledgeable and passionate about cave conservation." Another reviewer mentioned, "Fricks Cave is a hidden gem with a unique ecosystem. The annual open house is a must-attend for nature enthusiasts"​​.

Fricks Cave Preserve offers a unique and educational experience focused on cave conservation and the protection of endangered species. For more information, you can visit the official website.
Whether you're an experienced spelunker or a curious traveler, Chattanooga's caves offer something for everyone. Guided tours provide a safe and informative way to explore these underground wonders, with knowledgeable guides sharing fascinating details about the caves' history, geology, and ecology. For the more adventurous, wild cave tours present the chance to delve deeper into the less accessible parts of these cave systems, offering a truly immersive experience.

Visiting Chattanooga's caves is not just about the thrill of exploration; it's also about education and stewardship. By learning about the caves and their significance, visitors gain a deeper appreciation for the natural world and the importance of preserving it. This awareness helps foster a community of conservation-minded individuals dedicated to protecting these invaluable resources for future generations.

title: Exploring Chattanooga’s Civil War Landmarks
body:
A Solider in the stillness of an open field
Every hill, ridge and river crossing bears testimony to the titanic struggle between the two great armies during one of the deadliest campaigns of The War. It is the sacrifices, strategies and sheer determination that made up two opposing armies fighting for control of such a vital gateway to what came to define America forever.Quite simply it helped win the war.

From the imposing ridgeline of Missionary Ridge, where Union forces overcame a surprising and dramatic Confederate assault, to the contemplative Tower at Orchard Knob (where General Ulysses S. Grant planned his campaign) each site is an evocative reminder of those fateful days around Chattanooga well more than 150 years ago. The Battle of Brown's Ferry, although clouded by more famous battles that occurred during the same time frame is very important as it marked a key point in breaking the Confederate siege on Chattanooga and establishing control over "Wauhatchie", aka the all-important ‘Cracker Line’, which would keep vital supplies flowing to sustain clear victory for Federal forces here through this part of 1863.

In this guide, you'll be offered a guided walking tour of these historic places — not just where they are and what to expect when you get there, but the stories contained within them as well. Wether or not you are walking the same ground where generals planned their next move, or standing where ordinary soldiers performed extraordinary feats of arms these places bring to life the Civil War in almost a way only experienced by those who have had this experience. This is a must-see tour for any student of the Civil War, allowing one to explore America as it lived during and just after this flashpoint conflict.

1.  Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park

Where: Chickamauga Battlefield Visitor Center, 3370 LaFayette Road, Fort Oglethorpe

The oldest and largest military park in the United States, the Chickamauga & Chattanooga National Military Park is dedicated to two major battles from the Civil War.

The Battle of Chickamauga was fought in September 1863, and led to one of the biggest Confederate victories but also contributed to Union success during its Chattanooga Campaign. The park was created in 1890 to give visitors a chance to understand this immersive Civil War experience and walk the battlefields, view memorials, as well as see what strategies were used at that time by soldiers who fight up there.

Major sites include the Chickamauga Battlefield, Lookout Mountain and Missionary Ridge. The point of interest in this spot is no doubt the battles but that are recorded live from all locations which give a good view and feel what fights was like especially as most landscapes have not majorly change: across acreage (the time )manifestations harking back to during war. Visitor centers come with exhibits, films and artifacts which makes it a learning experience for all ages.

In addition to providing a wealth of history, the park also boasts picturesque views -- noteably from Lookout Mountain in what is now known as "The Battle Above The Clouds" The Wilder Tower overlooks the Chickamauga Battlefield and offer sweeping vistas of all that surrounds it. The crowds can fluctuate, spring and fall are the busiest season because of the moderate weather (Fall is peak "leaf peeping" time too) but year around people visiting MIBS.

The visitor centers are usually open daily from 8:30 AM to five PM, with the park grounds open dawn till dusk. You are advised to go on the early mornings or late afternoons as many people want to make a weekend of it. The park is accessible to those with mobility issues, though some trails are more handicap friendly than others.

2.  Point Park - Lookout Mountain Battlefield

Where: 110 Point Park Rd, Lookout Mountain, TN 37350

Patt Park sits on top of Lookout Mountain, Tennessee… and teaches so much more than Civil War battles This is a web site dedicated to preserving the history of The Battle Above The Clouds, an action which contributed significantly in determining the outcome of "The Chattanooga Campaign" during when our fore-bearers were involved for better or worse in events that would effectively settle by arms if not persuasion whether this blessed United States was going be only noted as Was but rather indicated present opposite. The park is part of the larger Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park, which combines history with an amazing display of natural beauty.

On 24 November, Union forces under Major General Joseph Hooker made a movement up Lookout Mountain and dislodged Confederate troops who were in entrenched positions there. Lifted the Confederate siege of Chattanooga and opened up a chance for Union victory at Missionary Ridge on Nov. It was a minor skirmish in the war, but that tiny battle had wide-ranging ramifications and Point Park is there to remind us of such an important moment.

The park was founded in 1895, and it gives visitors the opportunity to explore this historic area. The New York Peace Memorial, a huge monument in the park, within depicts symbolizes reconciliation between North and South with Union hand Confederate soldiers appearing to be shaking hands. At 85 feet tall, this memorial is one of the most dominant in a park full of them.

Point Park is typically less crowded than many Chattanooga attractions, so it's a good place to visit if you enjoy solitude. The park is large and there are plenty of trails, so you always have space to think about the history or just look around at nature. Heritage Transport Museum — This museum is open from 10 AM to 7 PM, but the best timings are early morning or late evening when light will be better and it's less hot. The vibrant colors in the landscape make spring and fall are especially great times of year to visit, when they create an opportunity for enjoying truly nice weather.

Ochs Memorial Observatory is one of the parks tour highlights and gives some awesome panoramic views over Lookout Valley down to the Tennessee River with Chattanooga in sight below. The observatory, named after Adolph S. Ochs who was the publisher of The New York Times and played a pivotal role in preserving Lookout Mountain as all but needed local land for parkland purposes (he also helped secure funding from Rockefeller), is a great spot to get your photography fix or take it easy on some absolutely stunning views!
Enduring Symbols from History

3.  National Medal of Honor Heritage Center

Where: 2 W Aquarium Way, Suite 104, Chattanooga, TN 37402

The National Medal of Honor Heritage Center, located in Chattanooga, Tennessee is a tribute to the courage and sacrifice of over 3,500 known recipients who have received our nation's highest military honor. More than a museum, this center provides an in-depth and personal view of the inspiring people who have received one of American history's highest distinctions.

Situated in Downtown Chattanooga at 2 W Aquarium Way, Suite 104, the center is located within a city steeped in storied Medal of Honor tradition. Since the Civil War, this is where over half of Medals of Honor have been awarded and why it was chosen for the Heritage Center. The new, modern and spacious venue moved from a smaller location to the same lake front headquarters in Lake Geneva Wisconsin, officially opening it's doors February of 2020 for visitors.

At the center, visitors can experience immersive exhibits that bring to life the stories of Medal of Honor recipients. Articulately arranged, these exhibits comprehensively detail the debut of the Medal Of Honor during The Civil War through present. It is a point of education and inspiration where the values of courage, sacrifice, duty and patriotism are promoted in an exceptional way.

Open daily from 10 AM to five PM Closed Thanksgiving, Christmas Day and New Year's Day. Reasonably priced at about $15 for adults, with seniors treated to a discount along with military personnel and children. Fully accessible by ramps and elevators — everyone will be able to enjoy a visit!

4.  Battles for Chattanooga Museum

Location: 1110 East Brow Road, Lookout Mountain, TN 37350

Battles for Chattanooga Museum — On Lookout Mountain; a dramatic, interactive museum exploring one of the most influential decades in American history: The Decade That Created Modern America. For those interested in Chattanooga's significant role during the Ar of Rebllion, especially later months of 1863 because it all began to crumble and became battle lines for Union and Confederate Forces fighting over this vital transportation center..This museum is a must see.

The museum's central attraction is its giant 3D electronic battle map, which shows a half-hour overview of the entire Chattanooga Campaign More than simply informative, this is an interactive and educational must-see feature that helps visitors to better understand what happened on the battlefield.

The museum is open daily from 9 AM to 5 PM, except for Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day. The cost of admission is low and broadly accessible. A museum that offers quite a fulfilling experience for those who visit. In addition to the 3D battle map, it houses another cache of Civil War relics: weapons, uniforms and personal items from real soldiers. Eloquently curated as they are, these more old-fashioned exhibits remain a useful bridge to those who actually fought in the battles around Chattanooga.

5.  Moccasin Bend National Archeological District

Location: Moccasin Bend Road, Chattanooga, TN 37405

The Moccasin Bend National Archeological District -located in Chattanooga, Tennessee- has a historic significance that can be traced back to for at least the Civil War. Rising 160 feet above the bend is Moccasin Bend, long famous for its archaeological significance; evidence of human society on this promontory has been found dating back to over twelve millenniums ago exactly at a time when men would soon gather with tanks and planes across the world in Europe — but also as far East were Russia and Japan fought their war.

Drawing on a Tribune of the People inspector making his way to Chattanooga,National Park ServiceExpress/Getty ImagesDuring the war, Moccasin Bend — and its location along the Tennessee River — proved important for Union forces. This natural positioning was a great benefit for the Union army, which would be able to shell Lookout Mountain via artillery during "The Battle Above The Clouds" on November 24th. Several weeks later, Union forces including Wilder's men captured Chattanooga from the Confederates in a campaign that was crucial to driving the Rebel army back south and out of Tennessee due its important position at railroads and supply lines.

But in an age before highways and railroads, the river offered a vital route for carrying supplies to soldiers fighting on other parts of the war's battlegrounds. Claiming this area guided Sherman down a path towards one of his biggest victories — leading to the Atlanta Campaign and forward onto perhaps Sherman's greatest legacy, The March to the Sea.
Today Moccasin Bend is a component of the Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park, these lands are protected for both their archaeologically significant past as well as Civil War history. A system of trails allows visitors to move through the area, offering views of the Tennessee River and Lookout Mountain that connect not only historically but physically with what occurred here. The trails are well-signed interpretive and informational signs add context to all the views.

6.  Missionary Ridge

Location: Missionary Ridge Road, Chattanooga, TN

The Chattanooga Campaign ended after one of its most critical battles, the Battle of Missionary Ridge in Chattanooga (Tennessee), which made it a historic site during the days when Arkansas was part-and-parcel with fighting against slavery. Because this low, thin hill experienced a dramatic Federal triumph that was crucial to the war's result Thursday vacation spot for visitors with an interest in history.

November 22, 1863 The Battle of Missionary Ridge was the climax to an offensive operation by Union forces against the fortified positions held by a Confederate force under Gen. After taking success at Lookout Mountain and Orchard Knob, the Union forces led by General Ulysses S. Grant attacked the fortified positions well entrenched on ridges held in numbers for great effect of Confederate troops. A diversionary attack that escalated into a charge on the whole line. When the Confederates launched an attack on Sherman Blue led by Patrick Cleburne from a mountain 500 feet above, tens of thousands of Union soldiers spontaneously advanced up the steep slopes to their front and tore through working guns at Missionary Ridge alignment. The stunning victory shifted the tide of battle and also established Chattanooga as a cornerstone to Union power in Tennessee, which allowed for future Major General William T. Sherman's Atlanta Campaign later that year.

Today, Missionary Ridge is a quiet residential community but it still remembers the past with numerous markers, monuments and reservations denoting the battle. The ridge can be visited by driving Missionary Ridge Road which generally runs the crest of the ridge and would give visitors access to sites such as Bragg Reservation (which is located about a mile beyond where I stood watching you on Goodwin Avenue) or perhaps DeLong Reservation. From these locations you can see for miles and get an idea of the significance the ridge held to troops.

The site remains open year round, has no specific hours of operation and is free for the public to come visit any time they like. Being predominantly residential, Missionary Ridge is never as crowded as other Civil War sites in Chattanooga and offers a serene opportunity for reflection
Historical Monument in Reflection

7.  Brown's Ferry Federal Road

Location: Brown’s Ferry Road, Chattanooga, TN 37419

A modest but supremely significant Civil War-related venue, the Brown's Ferry Federal Road near Chattanooga, Tennessee. It may not be home to the sweeping vistas of other battlegrounds, but Chickamauga played a crucial role in Union success during the Chattanooga Campaign and provides students interested in military logistics, strategy, and planning visited the site as they depart for their winter encampment.

The Union army in Chattanooga, Tennessee was trapped and under siege by Confederate forces commanded by General Braxton Bragg. If they ran out of food, the Union soldiers were going to be in serious trouble without supply lines. Union generals including Ulysses S. Grant, George Thomas and William T. Sherman then learned of the situation in Chattanooga and planned a risky operation at Brown's Ferry to reopen supply lines During the night of October 27,1863 Union forces launched a rarely successful nighttime raid on this Ferry, and freed it from Confederate control. This operation enabled the Union to open and maintain the "Cracker Line," a critical supply route that thwarted Rosecrans' defeat, saved his army at Chattanooga. It was a masterstroke of military strategy and played an important role in the eventual Union triumph during this campaign.

An often ignored historic footprint, Brown's Ferry is a meandering expanse for many seeking to reflect upon the significance of this time in American history. The road and ferry crossing are accessible from the Lookout Valley end of Chattanooga, Tenn., with no regular hours or entrance fees -- so you're free to visit anytime. The area is not over developed for tourism so it still feels somewhat authentic and non-commercialised.

8.  Orchard Knob

Address: 200 E. 4th Street, Chattanooga, TN 37403

The straight line crosses over Orchard Knob, a small hill in Chattanooga that bears tremendous historical significance from the Civil War. This site was just as important during the Chattanooga Campaign of 1863, although it's not nearly as spectacular to view. During the offensive, Union General James Longstreet used Surgeons Hill as a vital observation point from which he could direct his troops and see farther ahead than any Confederates.

The following day, November 23 rd, General Ulysses S. Grant commanded Union troops to attack Orchard Knob and captured it from Confederate fighters. Moreover, this position also granted the Union commanders a full perspective of their environment which was perfect for devising/planning the later attacks on Missionary Ridge and Lookout Mountain. Here Grant and his generals directed the assaults that would end a Confederate siege on Chattanooga by turning it into one of the most important Union bases, which indeed marked an pivotal point in Civil War.

Today, Orchard Knob, a site for reflection in an urban area of Chattanooga. You can visit it now at 200 E. 4th Street to stand in the same spot as would-be world travelers of two centuries ago, and consider what happened there was a “big deal.” Numerous National Park Service maintaining monuments and historical information markers have been placed on the site to remember what happened there, The United States Union divisions that fought in this battle.

Discover Chattanooga's Civil War Heritage

By the end of your tour, Chattanooga's Civil War story is no longer some abstract series of markers over centuries-old fields; with every footfall on these battlegrounds you will feel yourself walking in hallowed steps through American history deserving its monuments. Whether the strategic brilliance of Brown's Ferry where Union troops broke open a key supply line that would ultimately change fate and fortunes, to soldiers refusing all odds at Missionary Ridge with dramatic heights right within sightline from one another – each site offers its own distinct lens into both great adversity as well as success which helped define this critical engagement.

title: A Guide to Georgia’s Best State Park 20 Miles from Chattanooga
body:
Cloudland Canyon Vista
Travel a bit south of Chattanooga (~20-25 miles depending) and you likely won't regret a trip to Cloudland Canyon State Park in Rising Fawn, Georgia. It was recently featured on The Discoverer as the best state park in Georgia. After investigating a little further you'll quickly find out why. It has over 60 miles of hiking, biking, and horseback riding trails ranging from easy to difficult with some of the best views you could hope for. There's plenty to do with the whole family for a day or weekend visit. In this guide let's take a look at more of what this nearby trail system treasure has to offer.

Trail Map pdf

Easier Hikes.

1.Meadowlands Trail
Distance: 1 mile
Directions

This is a one mile out and back trail. Off this trail you can fish for catfish. You don't even need a license, if the Interpretive Center is open they have fishing poles you can use, free of charge. The pond is stocked with catfish, the catch and keep season runs from Labor Day - December. Closest parking for this trail is at the Park Disc Golf course.

On this hike is an observation deck that offers a breathtaking view of the canyon vistas, be sure to stop and stare for a little while, maybe get a picture or maybe just store it in the old memory bank. In the summer there are blackberry bushes, with thousands of berries ripe for picking.


2.Overlook Trail
Distance: 1 mile
Directions
The Overlook Trail isn't frequently noted in the hiking apps but it is a good trail to know about if the lengths of the others are intimidating. This trail is easy to access as it sits right in front of the parking lot linked parking lot. It's a short out and back trail with spectacular views of the park, especially in the spring and fall. It's a great way to get a taste for the park or to start venturing back out into nature if it has been a little while since your last hiking adventure.

3.Backcountry Loop Trail
Distance: 2 miles
Rating: 4.6/5 AllTrails
Directions
There's no direct Google location for this trail. I linked to the closest parking in the directions above. This paired with the trail map should get you there. This is a trail loop to access primitive campsites and is also a nice 2 mile hike to explore a less frequently traveled, but still fairly easy hike. As with all of the other trails in the park remember to bring appropriate footwear, something that can handle moisture and rocky terrain. Like the Meadowlands Trail the closest parking will be at the disc golf course.
On the trail in CCSP

Easier MTB Rides.

The easier MTB rides below are from the 5 Points Recreation Area. Make sure you have proper gear and check the weather conditions and trail reports before your excursion.
1.Bankhead + Cloudland Canyon Connector + Shale Flats loop
Distance: 3-4 miles
Directions

This route makes use of three trails, each short in length. 1. Bankhead (0.4mi), 2. Shale Flats (1.1m) and 3. Cloudland Canyon Connector (CCC) (~1.7mi). All of these trails are bidirectional. It should be a little over a 3-4 mile bike ride in total. Each trail is designated as easy. Shale Flats is a total climb of 53 feet and Bankhead's climb is 73ft, unknown climb on this section of CCC but expect between 100-200 feet. The ride will take about 20-30 minutes in total depending on your speed and skill level.

You'll start out taking Bankhead a short ways before turning left onto CCC. Then you take CCC about another half of a mile before Shale Flats. Continue the entire 1.1 miles of Shale Flats before intersecting with CCC and Caprock, take CCC. Ride CCC back up to Bankhead and take Bankhead back to parking.

2.Cloudland Canyon Connector (and back)
Distance: 6.8 miles
Directions
Arguably the most popular trail in the 5 points system, take this trail out and back for close to a seven mile ride. You'll start by parking at the Ascalon Trailhead linked above and should be able to access CCC. The nice thing about this ride is it's a green the whole way and your main navigation note is to stay on the trail. CCC connects to many other trails in the 5 points network so you'll see a lot of forks, but just take CCC every time. The trail ends at Hinkie Road (RT 157). Then turn around and head back to Ascalon Trailhead where you parked.
5 Points MTB Trail Map

Intermediate/Advanced Hikes.

1.West Rim Loop
Distance: 4.7 miles
Directions

Nearly a 5 mile long loop style trail that keeps you on the outskirts of the canyon. As with any of the trails in this list make sure you wear proper footwear, it's pretty rugged. The trail features some beautiful views of the canyon as you take your lap around the park. This trail has in various years been rated one of the top hikes in the United States.


2.Waterfalls Trail
Distance: 1.8 miles
Directions

This trail is accessed off of the West Rim loop. Although shorter in distance, it's noted as probably the most strenuous trail in the park. It's recommended not to take your dog, as there are over 600 grated metal stairs that can be painful on their paws. The difficulty of this hiking trail is rewarded by the waterfalls, along this path is both the Hemlock and Cherokee falls. The waterflow varies, but will be best after a rainstorm.

3.Sitton's Gulch Trail
Distance: 6 miles
Directions

This is a 6 mile out and back trail. It will guide you down into the valley of the canyon as it follows along various creeks. In the springtime the wildflowers add for an extraordinary experience. It's a pretty difficult trail so be adequately prepared mentally and physically. Neaby are Sitton and Case cave's, accessible by guided tour only, so if you want to make it an even more adventurous day, be sure to book a tour in advance.

Hiking trails fork in the park

Intermediate/Advanced MTB Rides.

1.Tailings Run + CCC + North Hogsback
Distance: 4 - 5 miles
Directions

Park at 5 Points and begin riding north on Tailings Run, this is a 1.5 mile expert trail. Take Tailings to the Clouldland Canyon Connector (CCC) and ride the CCC (an easy trail) a few miles down until you get to the fork where a left turn will lead you onto the North Hogsback route. Note that once you get to 5 points, you're two thirds of the way through your ride on CCC. North Hogsback is another expert rated trail totaling 1.1 miles in distance. Take North Hogsback all the way to the 5 Points parking lot.


2.Bankhead + Kettle Bottom
Distance: 5 - 6 miles
Directions

Park at 5 Points and begin by taking Bankhead 0.4 miles to Clouldland Canyon Connector (CCC). Take a right on CCC until you get to the 5 Points intersection. At 5 Points find Kettle Bottom trail. Kettle Bottom is rated as an intermediate trail. You can either take it as a full loop or there is an alternate path that's slightly shorter (about 1/3 of a mile shorter). Both options take you back to 5 Points intersection where you'll take a right on CCC back to Bankhead and follow that back to the parking lot.

Disc Golf.

Holes: 18
Directions

Are you a disc golfer who's a sucker for scenery? The Cloudland Canyon State Park Disc Golf Course might be the course you're looking for. The course is easy to follow and well marked but some parts have been reported to be a little overgrown. The course has concrete tee's and though there are rest rooms in the state park, there are not restrooms readily available on the course. You have to pay the $5 entry fee to get into the park, but there's no additional fee after that. It's about a 5 minute drive from the park entrance to the course.


Disc and Target by formatc1. CC license 2.0.

Camping.

Park Campsite Map
Park Campsite Availability

Cloudland Canyon State Park offers pretty much every type of camping experience you have in mind. Want to camp out in a yurt? The have that. Want to bring your uncle Dave's RV? They have spots for that. Want to rent a cabin with friends? They can make that happen. You get the point. They also have primitive campsites for the folks who prefer the BYO tent lifestyle. There are additional fees depending on what you're doing, make sure to check their website for rental and campsite availablility and registration. In the popular season's (we're looking and you spring and fall) you may need to book a few weeks in advance.

Yurt Campgound by Bill Nicholls. CC license 2.0.
Cloudland Canyon State Park by Jeff Gunn. CC license 2.0.

Fishing.

The bad news? There is only one fishing spot in the campground. The good news? It's a pretty nice fishing spot. Cloudland Canyon has a pond that measures about one acre. It's stocked with channel catfish which can be harvested from the day after labor day through the end of November. All other times are catch and release. If you don't have your fishing license, don't fret it's not needed for this location.

The easiest way to access the pond is via the Meadowlands Trail, referenced above.

Important note: There is no fishing allowed in any of the park creeks.

Eating Nearby.

Are you visiting Cloudland Canyon for a day hike and want to get a bite to eat at a restaurant or cafe after? Maybe the fire wouldn't start to cook the frank and beans while you were camping. You have a few options nearby. Here are a few options:

1. Hope House Cafe. This cafe is a 10-15 minute drive from the mountain with great breakfast and lunch food options. It has charming atmosphere that's inviting after a day's hike.
2. Canyon Grill. If it's closer to dinnertime Canyon Grill will be what you're looking for. It has a great menu with highly rated seafood, steaks, and fried okra. The menu may have given it away but if it's not clear this is the most expensive option in this list. It's about 5-10 minutes from the park.
3. Thatcher's Bbq And Grille. A great lunch or dinner bbq option after your outdoor adventures, the menu features your bbq restaurant favorites like brisket and for dessert banana pudding. The menu has some gluten free options.

Other Ideas / Notes of Interest.

Road Bike .  The variys park areas are mostly interconnected through low-medium trafficked roads depending on when you visit. It can be a great place to ride your bike around nature, get some exercise, and potentially see some wildlife if you're lucky.
Horseback Ride .  There are some trails in the park that allow for horseback riding. You have to BYO horse, no guided tours are provided by the park. Riding trails are at the 5 Points Recreation Area with parking at Ascalon Trailhead.
Picnic .  Some free access picnic tables are scattered throughout the park, but you can also rent a larger picnic table for an event or family function. Find availability here.
Waterfalls .  Waterfalls. If you read through this guide (thanks if you did, big fan of you) you will have seen multiple mentions of waterfalls in the park. There's Hemlock Falls and Cherokee Falls, both are most easily accessed via the Meadowlands Trail. The water levels can vary significantly depending on rainfall but when they are flowing it's really a sight to behold.
Events .  Throughout the year this state parks hosts a wide variety of outdoor events, usually 5-10 per month. See if there is something you might like at GA State Parks website.
Volunteer .  Friends of Cloudland Canyon State Park are almost always seeking volunteers for various maintenance, hospitality, and fundraising roles regularly. If you're interested in helping maintain this wonderful park you can find more details here.

Closing Time.

I hope this guide left you feeling inspired for a visit to this magical park. I know I'm ready to go back now after putting it together. If you feel like I left anything out or you have any questions please reach out to jack@thingshappening.com

Local Coffee of East Ridge, located at 5330 Ringgold Rd, East Ridge, TN 37412, is a cozy coffee shop known for its welcoming atmosphere and friendly staff. This cafe provides a great environment for relaxing, socializing, or getting some work done.

The cafe offers a variety of coffee and food options. The coffee menu includes classic choices like espresso, drip coffee, and specialty drinks such as iced lattes and moccachinos. They also serve tasty baked goods and light meals, with popular items including cinnamon rolls, muffins, and soup. Occasionally, paninis and other savory items are featured.

Local Coffee of East Ridge has established itself as a beloved local spot, appreciated for its cozy atmosphere and excellent service.

Visitors often highlight the cozy and relaxing atmosphere of the cafe. The staff is praised for their friendliness and efficiency. The cafe tends to be less crowded in the mid-morning and early afternoon, making these the best times to visit for a quieter experience. It’s a great place to enjoy a cup of coffee, a light meal, or to host small gatherings.

One visitor shared, "I absolutely love this place. Me and my boyfriend come here every Saturday and any other day he isn't working. The staff is fantastic. The coffee here is the best. The atmosphere here is the best. The people are the best. It’s really just the best." Another reviewer mentioned, "What a place to enjoy a nice cup of coffee and amazing food! Perfect that it's local and easy access for a long stay or a quick visit when I am on the go. I would recommend this place over any other!! Come check it out for yourself!"

Local Coffee of East Ridge offers a delightful coffee experience with its excellent beverages, delicious food, and inviting atmosphere. It’s a must-visit spot for anyone in East Ridge looking for a great cup of coffee and a comfortable place to relax. For more information, you can visit their official page.

9.  Mayfly Coffee - Signal Mountain, TN

Mayfly Coffee, located at 708 Mississippi Ave, Signal Mountain, TN 37377, is a cozy coffee shop known for its warm and inviting atmosphere. This cafe is perfect for enjoying a cup of coffee, meeting friends, or getting some work done.

The cafe offers a diverse menu with a focus on freshly roasted, high-quality coffee. Their offerings include a range of single-origin coffees and unique blends such as the Dead Drift from Mexico and the Ascent from Peru. Seasonal lattes, espresso drinks, and popular items like the salted caramel peanut butter and white chocolate espresso are customer favorites.

In addition to coffee, Mayfly Coffee serves a variety of food items, including breakfast sandwiches, bagels, rolls, and pastries like blueberry muffins and cinnamon rolls. The Mabbit Springs burrito and Taft on an everything bagel are particularly popular. The cafe also offers draft beer, making it a great spot for both morning and afternoon visits.

Mayfly Coffee is part of the Cadence Coffee Company family and reflects a love for adventure and the outdoors. The shop is known for its commitment to quality and community involvement.

Visitors often praise the friendly staff and the delicious coffee. With plenty of seating and outlets, it's an ideal place for a cozy work session. The best times to visit are during mid-morning or early afternoon on weekdays to avoid the crowds. The cafe is open Monday to Saturday from 7 AM to 3 PM and is closed on Sundays.

"I love Dead Drift! It is amazing, smooth, bold… perfection in a cup!!!" Another reviewer mentioned, "Used to live in the Chattanooga area and enjoyed going to Mayfly coffee to try all of the different varieties and roasts they offer. I moved to the Detroit area and still order the coffee online when I can. Great place, great coffee, always freshly roasted, very reliable deliveries. Would recommend trying them all. Base camp is my favorite."

Mayfly Coffee offers a unique and enjoyable coffee experience with its excellent beverages, delicious food, and welcoming atmosphere. It’s a must-visit spot for anyone on Signal Mountain looking for a great cup of coffee and a comfortable place to relax. For more information, you can visit their official website.
Inviting cafe exterior and patio

10.  Be Caffeinated - Red Bank, TN

Be Caffeinated, located at 3601 Dayton Blvd, Red Bank, TN 37415, is a cozy coffee shop known for its community-focused atmosphere. This cafe primarily operates as a drive-thru, making it a convenient stop for commuters in the Red Bank/Hixson area. The Red Bank location, which opened in 2019, emphasizes fostering community, cultivating kindness, and ensuring a joyful experience for both customers and employees.

The cafe offers a diverse range of coffee drinks and other beverages. Popular options include the Blueberry Moc-Iatto, Hazelnut Bliss, Chattahooligan, Fresh Brewed Coffee, and French Press. In addition to coffee, Be Caffeinated serves a selection of pastries and light snacks, featuring items like Asiago bagels and other baked goods sourced from local suppliers. Seasonal drinks are also available, keeping the menu fresh and exciting.

Founded by Chris Wood and Doug Lee, Be Caffeinated started in Red Bank and has expanded to multiple locations around Chattanooga. The brand is committed to supporting the local community by sourcing products locally and participating in local charities. Their roasting operations are managed by New Wave Coffee Roasters, known for their musically inspired roasts and award-winning coffee.

Visitors often praise the friendly and knowledgeable staff, who are known for catering to dietary restrictions and offering personalized recommendations. The atmosphere is welcoming, making it a favorite spot for many locals. The drive-thru setup ensures quick service, but it can get busy during peak hours, such as weekday mornings. It's recommended to visit during mid-morning or early afternoon to avoid the rush.

"I absolutely love this place. Me and my boyfriend come here every Saturday and any other day he isn't working. The staff is fantastic. The coffee here is the best. The atmosphere here is the best. The people are the best. It’s really just the best." Another reviewer mentioned, "What a place to enjoy a nice cup of coffee and amazing food! Perfect that it's local and easy access for a long stay or a quick visit when I am on the go. I would recommend this place over any other!! Come check it out for yourself!"

Be Caffeinated offers a unique and enjoyable coffee experience with its excellent beverages, delicious food, and community-driven mission. It’s a must-visit spot for anyone in Red Bank looking for a great cup of coffee and a welcoming atmosphere. For more information, you can visit their official website.

11.  4 Corners Cafe - Ooltewah, TN

4 Corners Cafe, located at 9408 Apison Pike #102, Ooltewah, TN 37363, is a welcoming and cozy cafe known for its friendly and efficient staff. This cafe offers a casual dining experience that is perfect for both locals and visitors.

The menu at 4 Corners Cafe features a variety of coffee drinks and food options. Popular items include the chai latte, mocha Frostaccino, and various espresso drinks. For breakfast, they offer options like breakfast burritos and pastries. Lunch and dinner options include the Pesto Turkey Panini, Reuben sandwich, Hawaiian Chicken, Avocado Melt, Tuna Melt, and Chicken Salad Sandwich. The cafe caters to different dietary preferences with vegetarian and organic options available.

4 Corners Cafe has established itself as a beloved local spot in Ooltewah. The cafe prides itself on offering high-quality food and beverages while fostering a community atmosphere. Their mission is to provide excellent service and delicious meals to all their customers, making it a staple in the area.

Visitors frequently praise the friendly service, delicious food, and great coffee. The cafe offers a free library and plays fantastic music, adding to its cozy charm. The prices are reasonable, and the portions are generous. It tends to get busy during breakfast and lunch hours, so visiting mid-morning or early afternoon might provide a more relaxed experience.

"Very very friendly. Large amount of food and the food was great!!! The best chicken salad sandwich I've eaten in ANY restaurant." Another reviewer mentioned, "I had a Reuben and my husband had a Chicken Salad sandwich. We both agreed it was the best sandwich we have had in a long time. We will be back to dine in next time. If you have not eaten there, you should give it a try - YUMMY."

4 Corners Cafe is a must-visit spot in Ooltewah for its excellent food, friendly service, and inviting atmosphere. Whether you're stopping by for a quick coffee or a full meal, the cafe offers a delightful experience. For more information, you can visit their Restaurantji page.


Exploring these coffee spots will not only satisfy your caffeine cravings but also immerse you in the rich tapestry of local culture and hospitality. Each cafe offers a unique atmosphere and menu, reflecting the diverse flavors and experiences of the community. From the artisan brews at Mayfly Coffee to the community-driven mission of Be Caffeinated, and the cozy charm of 4 Corners Cafe, these establishments provide more than just a cup of coffee—they offer a slice of local life.

We encourage you to explore these local gems and discover your favorite spot. And if you have any recommendations or know of hidden gems that should be added to the list, we'd love to hear from you! Sharing your experiences and discoveries helps us all enjoy the best our local coffee culture has to offer. So, next time you're in the mood for a great cup of coffee, consider visiting one of these cafes and experiencing the local flavor and hospitality firsthand.
