title: 9 Dog-Friendly Restaurants and Coffeeshops
body:
Dog sitting patiently in front of his pup cup
Chattanooga, a city celebrated for its lively culinary scene and stunning natural beauty, is a fantastic destination for dog owners who want to enjoy dining out without leaving their furry companions behind. Whether you're a resident or just passing through, exploring Chattanooga with your dog adds a special dimension to your visit, especially when you know where to find the most welcoming spots for pets. From cozy cafes tucked away in charming neighborhoods to popular restaurants bustling with activity, this guide showcases the best dog-friendly dining options in the city. These establishments go beyond simply allowing dogs—they make sure your canine friend is part of the experience, offering water bowls, treats, and even special menu items. As you leash up your pup and head out, you'll discover that Chattanooga's dog-friendly restaurants are as diverse as the city itself, ensuring a memorable outing for both you and your four-legged companion. Here's a look at the top places where dogs are not just permitted but warmly embraced, making every meal an opportunity to enjoy the city's hospitality together.

1.  Play Wash Pint - Chattanooga, TN

Play Wash Pint, located at 113 Johnson Street, Chattanooga, TN 37408, is a unique venue combining a dog park, self-wash station, and beer garden. This venue offers a safe, clean, and enjoyable space for dogs and their owners to socialize and play.

The park features three separate areas: a small dog yard, a social mixer yard for all sizes, and a fetch zone. Amenities include pet-grade turf, custom dog fountains, misters, fans, heaters, and covered areas for year-round comfort. Additionally, the venue offers a groomer-quality self-wash station available for half-hour bookings.

Opened in September 2017 by Bob and Courtney Poore, Play Wash Pint addresses the lack of well-maintained, supervised dog parks in Chattanooga. Their mission is to provide a community hub for dog lovers, offering proper exercise and socialization for dogs and a place for humans to relax and enjoy craft beers.

Play Wash Pint offers several membership options:
  • Daily Pass: $10 per dog
  • Quarterly Membership: $100 for three months ($50 for each additional dog)
  • Annual Membership: $250 per year ($125 for each additional dog)
Members enjoy benefits like daily beer specials, self-wash station discounts, free entry to ticketed events, daycare discounts, and more.

Operating Hours:
  • Monday to Thursday: 4 PM - 9 PM
  • Friday to Sunday: 12 PM - 9 PM
  • Saturday and Sunday Member Only Hours: 10 AM - 12 PM

The venue offers a rotating menu of over 60 beers, ciders, and seltzers. Some popular choices include That Coconut Porter from Cherry Street Brewing and various local craft options. The beer garden provides a relaxing atmosphere for patrons to enjoy their drinks while watching their dogs play.

Visitors frequently praise the clean, well-maintained facilities and the friendly, attentive staff. Here are a couple of reviews:
"A place of community for pet lovers and beer drinkers alike!! Awesome customer service, awesome space, awesome beer. It really doesn't get any better than this place!" - Kiersten W.
"The cleanliness and uniqueness of this dog park/facility is outstanding. Love the cute equipment and turf. My dog had a blast and the atmosphere was nice as well" - Ellie W.

Tips for Visiting:
  • Ensure your dog is up-to-date on Rabies, DHPP, and Bordetella vaccines, and is spayed or neutered if over one year old.
  • Consider visiting during member-only hours on weekends for a quieter experience.
  • Even if you don’t have a dog, the venue welcomes you to enjoy the atmosphere and drinks.

Play Wash Pint is a must-visit spot in Chattanooga for dog owners and dog lovers. For more information, visit their official website or their page on Visit Chattanooga.

2.  GoDog - Chattanooga, TN

GoDog, located at 255 W 20th St, Chattanooga, TN 37408, is a premier pet facility offering a variety of services including dog daycare, boarding, grooming, and a social dog park and bar. This venue is a top destination for pet owners in Chattanooga.

The daycare program (GoDog:PLAY) features indoor and outdoor play yards, dog playground equipment, and daily sanitized canine turf. The price is $36 per day, with various package options available for multiple days and multiple dogs.

The boarding service (GoDog:STAY) includes participation in the daycare program during the day. The boarding facilities are equipped with medical-grade HVAC systems for fresh, filtered air. Prices start at $60 per night for a single pet, with accommodations available for multiple pets in various room sizes.

Grooming services (GoDog:BATHE) range from basic baths to deluxe treatments that include nail trims, brush-outs, and more. Prices start at $20 for nail trims and $45 for deluxe baths.

Custom-tailored obedience training programs (GoDog:BEHAVE) are available, including immersive board and train options to help your dog master good manners.

The outdoor dog park (GoDog:SOCIAL) includes an 8,000-square-foot play yard, a covered patio, and a bar area. The bar serves local craft brews and non-alcoholic options for both dogs and humans. Food trucks are also available on-site, making it a great spot to socialize while your dog plays. Social hours are Wednesday to Friday from 4 PM to 8 PM, Saturday from 3 PM to 9 PM, and Sunday from 11 AM to 7 PM (with small dog hours from 11 AM to 1 PM).

Membership and Fees:
  • Daily Pass: $10 per dog
  • Monthly Membership: $30 for one pet, $45 for two pets
  • Annual Membership: $300 for one pet, $450 for two pets

Tips for Visiting:
  • Ensure your dog is up-to-date on required vaccinations (Rabies, Distemper, and Bordetella) and is spayed or neutered if over six months old.
  • The venue tends to be busiest on weekends, so visiting during weekdays or early in the morning might provide a more relaxed experience.
  • Even if you don’t have a dog, you can enjoy the bar and food trucks while watching the dogs play.

Visitors often praise the cleanliness of the facility and the friendliness of the staff. Here are a couple of reviews:
"With my busy and sporadic schedule, GoDog is the perfect place for Chewie to burn energy and get great socialization in a safe environment. I also love that the staff separates the sizes of dogs for playtime. The staff is so friendly and accommodating!" - Jennifer
"The staff is very attentive, and the facility is top-notch. My dog loves it here, and I enjoy the atmosphere and the drinks while he plays." - Anonymous

GoDog is a must-visit spot in Chattanooga for dog owners and dog lovers. For more information, visit their official website or their profile on BBB.

3.  The Bitter Alibi - Chattanooga, TN

The Bitter Alibi, located at 825 Houston Street, Chattanooga, TN 37403, is a unique dive bar and restaurant situated in a charming three-story house. It offers a cozy and inviting atmosphere for patrons to enjoy food and drinks.

Opened in 2014, The Bitter Alibi started as a basement bar serving food made in crockpots and panini presses. Over the years, it has expanded to include two additional floors, enhancing its kitchen offerings while maintaining its welcoming vibe.

The venue spans three floors, with the third floor housing a new cocktail bar called Dilemma. The Bitter Alibi is known for its quirky and energetic atmosphere, making it a popular spot for locals and visitors alike.

The bar features a wide selection of craft beers, specialty cocktails, and local brews. Popular drinks include the gin mule and jalapeño margarita. The menu is diverse, with options like wonton nachos, pork belly ramen, and various brunch items. Vegan and vegetarian options are also available. The third-floor cocktail bar, Dilemma, offers a variety of expertly crafted cocktails.

Operating Hours:
  • Monday - Saturday: 4:00 PM - Midnight
  • Sunday: 10:00 AM - Midnight (Brunch from 10:00 AM - 3:00 PM)

The Bitter Alibi is pet-friendly, with outdoor seating available where patrons can bring their dogs. This makes it a great spot for dog owners to enjoy a meal or drink while their pets relax nearby.

There is no entry fee to visit The Bitter Alibi. It operates as a typical bar and restaurant where patrons pay for food and drinks as they order. The venue can get busy, especially during weekend brunch and evening hours. For a more relaxed experience, consider visiting during weekday evenings or early on Sunday mornings.

Visitors often praise the friendly and efficient staff, as well as the delicious food and drink offerings. Here are a couple of reviews:
"Staff were friendly and fast. Had the wonton nachos, which were devoured by the family. Good tap beer selection and excellent gin mule." - Mark W.
"The Bitter Alibi has a nice selection of draft beers and specialty cocktails. The Loaded Wontons and Pork Belly Ramen were standout dishes. Looking forward to returning." - njylf
"The food is fabulous every single time and the jalapeño margarita is superb!" - Jocelyn Hill

Tips for Visiting:
  • The stairs can be tricky to navigate, especially when busy. Ask the staff for alternative routes if needed.
  • Try the specialty cocktails and the popular brunch items for a delightful experience.

The Bitter Alibi is a must-visit spot in Chattanooga for its excellent food, drinks, and lively atmosphere. For more information, visit their official website or check out their profile on Visit Chattanooga.

4.  Frothy Monkey - Chattanooga, TN

Frothy Monkey is located at 1400 Market Street, Chattanooga, TN 37402, within the historic Chattanooga Choo Choo Hotel. This cafe offers a charming and welcoming atmosphere, perfect for a variety of dining experiences from casual coffee breaks to full meals.

Originally founded in Nashville, Frothy Monkey has expanded to several locations, including this one in Chattanooga. Known for its focus on community and genuine hospitality, Frothy Monkey aims to create a space where guests can enjoy quality food and drinks throughout the day.

The menu at Frothy Monkey is diverse, catering to various dietary preferences with options for vegetarians, vegans, and those needing gluten-free choices. Popular items include French Toast with Macerated Berries, Loaded Biscuits and Chorizo Gravy, Farm Breakfast, Salmon Sandwich, Grilled Cheese, and Avocado Toast. Drink options feature the Turtle Latte, honey latte, and signature cocktails like Mimosas and draft beer.

Operating Hours: Daily: 7:00 AM - 9:00 PM

Frothy Monkey offers outdoor seating where dogs are welcome, making it a pet-friendly spot for dog owners to relax and enjoy their meals alongside their furry friends. The patio area is particularly popular for this purpose.

The cafe provides 15-minute parking for quick stops, with additional street-side parking available. There is also the nearby CARTA South Garage. The location is ADA compliant, offering accessible seating on the lower level and outdoors.

Frothy Monkey can get quite busy, especially during peak hours such as breakfast and brunch times. For a more relaxed experience, consider visiting during mid-morning or late afternoon on weekdays.

Visitors often praise the friendly and efficient staff, as well as the delicious food and drink offerings. Here are a couple of reviews:
"Great place for a healthy breakfast. The food was so good and the staff was so friendly we came back the next day for breakfast!" - Nick C.
"Delicious food in a beautiful setting. The staff was kind and accommodating, even offering a discount for a long wait. Highly recommended for gluten-free options." - Sarah H.
"Great coffee and breakfasts with excellent service in a nicely restored historic train station." - TheTwig

Tips for Visiting:
  • Try the specialty lattes and bakery items for a delightful treat.
  • The patio is perfect for enjoying good weather with your dog.
  • If you're in a hurry, take advantage of the curbside pickup or quick stop parking options.

Frothy Monkey is a must-visit spot in Chattanooga for its excellent food, drinks, and lively atmosphere. For more information, visit their official website or check out their profile on TripAdvisor.
Happy dog at the café

5.  Milk & Honey - Chattanooga, TN

Nestled in the vibrant Northshore neighborhood at 135 North Market Street, Chattanooga, Milk & Honey stands out as a beloved local gem. This charming cafe, part of the Monen Family Restaurant Group, has garnered a reputation for its commitment to quality, community, and genuinely delightful offerings.

Milk & Honey is more than just a cafe; it's a haven for those seeking the comforts of home-cooked meals with a touch of Southern flair. Known for its house-made gelato, craft coffee, and a variety of brunch staples, the cafe ensures that everything is made from scratch daily. The menu is diverse, catering to various dietary preferences with plenty of vegetarian and gluten-free options. Highlights include the Superfamous Buttermilk Biscuit, Veggie Breakfast Burrito, Short Rib Grilled Cheese, and Hot Chicken & Waffles.

From the moment you step in, Milk & Honey envelops you in a cozy atmosphere. The space features a combination of a coffeeshop area, a dining area, and outdoor seating. The latter is particularly popular among dog owners, as the cafe welcomes furry friends on its patio. This dog-friendly policy makes it a perfect spot for patrons to enjoy their meals while their pets relax by their side.

Like any popular spot, Milk & Honey can get quite busy, especially during weekend brunch hours. However, the staff's friendly and efficient service ensures that even peak times are managed smoothly. For those looking to avoid the crowds, mid-morning visits on weekdays are ideal.

Visitors frequently praise the cafe for its excellent service and high-quality food. A recent review highlighted the "cozy atmosphere and friendly service," noting the convenience of the location and ample parking. Another visitor appreciated the gluten-free options and the staff's accommodating nature, even when faced with service hiccups.

Operating Hours: Daily from 6:00 AM to 3:00 PM for kitchen service, while coffee and gelato are served until 6:00 PM.

Milk & Honey offers takeout, delivery, and curbside pickup options, making it easy for patrons to enjoy their favorites on the go.

Milk & Honey is a must-visit in Chattanooga for anyone seeking delicious, home-made meals in a warm, welcoming environment. Whether you're a local or just passing through, this cafe promises a memorable experience that keeps you coming back for more. For more information, visit their official website or check out their profile on Tripadvisor.

6.  The Daily Ration - Chattanooga, TN

Located at 1220 Dartmouth Street, Chattanooga, The Daily Ration has carved out a niche as a beloved local spot for breakfast, brunch, and lunch. Since opening its doors in May 2016, this cafe has become a cornerstone of the community, offering a warm and inviting atmosphere that feels like a home away from home.

The Daily Ration is the brainchild of the team behind The Bitter Alibi, and it carries the same ethos of community and quality. The bright, airy dining room and spacious patio provide the perfect backdrop for enjoying a leisurely meal, whether you're catching up with friends or grabbing a quick bite before work. The decor is casual yet stylish, with a focus on comfort and accessibility.

The menu at The Daily Ration is a delightful blend of classic American fare and inventive twists. For breakfast enthusiasts, the "Breakfast Plate" is a must-try, featuring two eggs cooked to order, breakfast potatoes, a choice of meat, and a fluffy biscuit. Another crowd favorite is the "Blueberry Flapjacks," served with whipped butter and bourbon maple syrup, striking the perfect balance between fluffy and hearty.

Brunch and lunch options are equally enticing. The "Fried Chicken & Waffles" and "Southern Benedict" showcase the kitchen's flair for combining traditional Southern flavors with contemporary techniques. The "D.R. Burger," stacked with lettuce, tomato, garlic aioli, bacon, cheddar, and a fried egg, is a testament to the cafe's commitment to hearty, flavorful dishes.

One of the standout features of The Daily Ration is its dog-friendly policy. The spacious patio is perfect for diners who want to enjoy a meal without leaving their furry friends at home. Reviews frequently mention the welcoming atmosphere for pets, making it a favorite among dog owners in the area.

Operating Hours: Daily from 8:00 AM to 2:00 PM.

It is advisable to visit during mid-morning on weekdays if you prefer a quieter experience, as weekends can get particularly busy during brunch hours. Despite the crowds, the friendly and efficient staff ensure that service remains top-notch.

The Daily Ration isn't just about food; it's about fostering a sense of community. The cafe often updates its menu, providing regulars with new dishes to try and ensuring that there's always something fresh and exciting on offer. This commitment to community and quality has earned it a loyal following and rave reviews from both locals and visitors.

Visitors from near and far have nothing but praise for The Daily Ration. One reviewer from Huntsville, AL, highlighted the "excellent service and amazing food," while another appreciated the pet-friendly environment and the addition of a rock area for kids to play. The comfort food, combined with a mission to support local businesses, makes The Daily Ration a standout in Chattanooga's vibrant food scene.

The Daily Ration offers a perfect blend of quality food, community spirit, and a welcoming atmosphere. Whether you're a local or just passing through, this cafe promises a memorable dining experience that keeps you coming back for more. For more information, visit their official website or their profile on Restaurantji.

7.  Rembrandt's Coffee House - Chattanooga, TN

Located in the heart of Chattanooga’s Bluff View Art District, Rembrandt’s Coffee House has been a cherished local spot since its establishment in 1994. Positioned at 204 High Street, this European-style cafe combines charm, comfort, and culinary excellence, making it a favorite among locals and visitors alike.

Rembrandt’s Coffee House exudes the ambiance of a quaint European cafe. Inside, it offers a warm and inviting atmosphere with displays of artisan breads, pastries, and locally roasted coffees. The outdoor patio is especially charming, featuring climbing vines and providing a picturesque setting, particularly during the fall when the leaves turn vibrant shades of red, yellow, and orange. This serene environment makes it an ideal spot for a relaxing coffee break or a leisurely afternoon with a book.

The menu at Rembrandt’s is as diverse as it is delicious, catering to a wide range of tastes and dietary preferences. Breakfast options include the French Toast Breakfast and the Egg and Cheese Sammy, while the pastry selection features delights such as the Double Decker Chocolate Cream Puff, Cream Cheese Brownie, and the Nutella Croissant. For those with a sweet tooth, the dessert pastries like the Chocolate Eclair and Toffee Walnut Bar are must-tries. The coffee bar offers an array of espresso and coffee-based beverages, including specialty drinks like the hazelnut bliss and hot chocolate.

Operating Hours: Rembrandt’s Coffee House is open daily from 8:00 AM to 9:00 PM, making it a convenient spot for breakfast, lunch, or an evening dessert. Despite its popularity, the cafe manages to maintain a cozy and inviting atmosphere, although visitors should be prepared for potential wait times during peak hours.

One of the standout features of Rembrandt’s is its dog-friendly policy. The outdoor patio welcomes dogs, allowing patrons to enjoy their meals alongside their furry friends. This has made Rembrandt’s a favorite among dog owners who appreciate the opportunity to relax in a charming setting without leaving their pets at home.

Reviews for Rembrandt’s are overwhelmingly positive, with patrons frequently praising the quality of the food and the delightful ambiance. One reviewer highlighted the “great coffee and pastries” and the ample outdoor space, while another mentioned the “friendly staff but long wait times,” suggesting that the cafe could benefit from additional staff during busy periods. Despite this, the overall consensus is that Rembrandt’s offers a wonderful experience that is well worth the visit.

Tips for Visiting: For the best experience, consider visiting during mid-morning on weekdays to avoid the crowds. Parking can be a bit challenging, so arriving early or being prepared to walk a short distance is advisable. After enjoying your meal, take some time to explore the Bluff View Art District, which features galleries, sculptures, and scenic views of the Tennessee River.

Rembrandt’s Coffee House is a must-visit destination in Chattanooga. Its combination of excellent food, charming atmosphere, and dog-friendly patio makes it a standout in the local dining scene. For more information, visit their official website.
Fido enjoying a visit to the coffee shop

8.  Beast + Barrel - Chattanooga, TN

Located at 16 Frazier Avenue in Chattanooga’s vibrant North Shore neighborhood, Beast + Barrel has been captivating diners since its opening in 2015. Part of a group of establishments including The Honest Pint and The Terminal Brewhouse, this gastro smokehouse and bar offers a unique blend of rustic charm and modern sophistication.

Beast + Barrel is the brainchild of the team behind some of Chattanooga's favorite spots. The venue exudes a cozy, rustic-chic atmosphere with a decor that combines reclaimed wood, exposed brick, and contemporary accents. It's an inviting space that feels both intimate and lively, making it perfect for both casual meals and special occasions.

The menu at Beast + Barrel is a delightful mix of traditional American fare with innovative twists. Highlights include:
  • Appetizers: Crispy Brussels sprouts and salmon tartare served with house-made chips.
  • Main Dishes: The Crescent City Chicken, a standout with its Cajun fried chicken, maple gravy, and goat cheese whipped potatoes, and the PB Burger, an unconventional but delicious burger topped with peanut butter, bacon, and red onions on a Niedlov’s bun.
  • Drinks: The drink menu is extensive, featuring a variety of craft beers, creative cocktails like the Spring Fling, and classics such as the Dirty Martini.

Operating Hours: Beast + Barrel operates from 3:00 PM to 10:00 PM Monday through Thursday, with extended hours on Friday until midnight, and from 10:00 AM to midnight on weekends. The venue is dog-friendly, particularly on its spacious outdoor patio, making it a great spot for pet owners to enjoy a meal with their furry friends.

Reviews for Beast + Barrel are generally positive, with patrons often praising the cozy atmosphere, attentive service, and flavorful dishes. One reviewer enjoyed the Crescent City Chicken, noting its perfect crispness and flavorful gravy, while another highlighted the surprisingly good PB Burger. However, some feedback points to occasional slow service and issues with food temperature, particularly during off-peak hours. Despite these minor hiccups, many patrons express their intent to return, drawn by the overall quality and ambiance.

Tips for a Great Visit:
  • Best Times to Visit: Weekday evenings are ideal to avoid the weekend rush. The venue can get particularly busy during peak dining hours, so plan accordingly.
  • Parking: There is ample street parking around the venue, but it can fill up quickly during busy times. Arriving early can help secure a spot.
  • Reservations: While not always necessary, calling ahead for larger groups is advisable to ensure seating availability.

In conclusion, Beast + Barrel offers a distinctive dining experience in Chattanooga’s North Shore. Its combination of innovative cuisine, extensive drink menu, and welcoming atmosphere make it a must-visit. For more details, visit their official website.

9.  The Blue Plate - Chattanooga, TN

Nestled at 191 Chestnut Street, Chattanooga, right across from Ross’s Landing and the Tennessee Aquarium, The Blue Plate has firmly established itself as a staple in the local dining scene. Since its inception, this modern diner has been celebrated for its comforting American fare and welcoming atmosphere, making it a go-to spot for both locals and tourists.

The Blue Plate strikes a perfect balance between retro diner charm and contemporary elegance. The interior is sectioned into small, cozy areas that prevent it from feeling overwhelming, while the outdoor patio offers diners a chance to enjoy their meals with stunning river views. title: Chattanooga Gems: A Guide to Unique Museums and Cultural Centers
body:
Timeless world of railroads
Chattanooga Tennessee is more than beautiful scenery and tourist destinations — it's a city loaded with history, culture and unexplored stories. Beyond the normal tourist hot spots there are a number of museums and cultural centers that also help tell more about Yerevan then you will get from taking photos in front landmarks. It is an experience that envelops you in the story of American life, both here and across the nation.

Prime examples include the Charles H. Coolidge National Medal of Honor Heritage Center, which provides a sobering yet stirring glance at the valor and sacrifice in living recipients of that hallowed award. In doing so, it is not a memorial to history but rather to the values that made us strong. In the same vein, can you imagine Chattanooga without both a Slave museum and Bessie Smith Cultural Center to record what happened on one side of Nashville or Hamilton County with broad strokes rather than just names?

EXPEDITION: BIGFOOT! sorts those who are a fan of the obscure. Feeler: An exploration of the Sasquatch Museum and one part of American lore. Either way, the museum is home to an entertaining collection of objects and anecdotes that are well worth a visit whether you lay skeptical or credulous stakes.

They serve as portals into worlds real or imagined; in the case of some there are that wallows with historical heroism, for others it is a serving buffet on cultural heritage and folklore. They deliver not just news, but also perspectives and understanding of the stories that make up this vibrant city. Add these to your list of things not too miss while in; Chattanooga. One thing they do guarantee is that you will walk away not only better informed, but with a sense of kinship to the individuals, cultures and histories that form this very special part of America.

1.  Tennessee Valley Railroad Museum

Location: 4119 Cromwell Rd, Chattanooga, TN 37421

But the Tennessee Valley Railroad Museum, in Chattanooga, takes things a step further -- taking visitors back to when rail travel was king at its real-life destination of yore. Something you will not find in your nose-in-the-air, static museum is a place where you walk right up and board hundred year old trains as they leave the platform for distant lands of time past.

That line is situated on a section of the old Southern Railway and includes the historic Missionary Ridge Tunnel, which opened in 1858 and is listed on National Register as an engineering historical site. The tunnel is an integral part of the popular Missionary Ridge Local ride, a 55-minute round-trip excursion to help us understand our railway history. En route, you will go over a number of bridges and through an active train yard where repairs are being done.

Started in 1961 by local railroad fans, the museum has developed into one of the Southeast's elite rail museums. With a fine operational fleet of both steam and diesel locomotives, passenger & freight rolling stock some in excess of 100 years old. The important role of the museum's restoration shop, which is named after co-founder Robert M. Soule, Jr., in keeping these historic machines running cannot be overstated.

Summerville Steam Special — as well from the short excursions on smaller apportioned rides. The nine-hour adventure includes a stop in Summerville, Georgia located within the Hiwassee River Gorge. The museum even hosts special events like the Harry-Potter-friendly hullabaloo "Rails, Wizards & Spells" ride.

Many visitors often comment on how the equipment is in good working condition and share stories of some of its enthusiastic volunteers that come out to help with the demonstration. The Missionary Ridge Local is especially popular with families because it affords a short, but interesting ride that's just right for little ones. Grounds are very well cared for, and the staff make each visit special- they often offer to take your picture in front of a locomotive.

Please verify operating hours as they change seasonally, but the museum typically opens at 9 AM with train rides during day light hours Tickets for the most popular excursions and special events are highly recommended to be booked in advance.

For an ideal experience, give yourself a weekday morning so that you can digest exhibits and rides at your leisure without the feeling of being hurried. There is plenty of free parking so easy for a quick getaway.

For rail buffs, or those seeking an experience that has more than a kernel of appeal for the historic and romantic inner child in most people, the Tennessee Valley Railroad Museum offers something to intrigue virtually everyone.

2.  Chattanooga Pinball Museum

Location: 409 Broad Street, Chattanooga, TN 37402

The Chattanooga Pinball Museum on Broad Street offers a vibrant and nostalgic experience that’s hard to find anywhere else. This isn't your typical museum filled with artifacts behind glass. Instead, it's an interactive playground where visitors of all ages can immerse themselves in the history and thrill of pinball and arcade games.

The museum’s collection includes over 40 classic pinball machines and retro arcade games, ranging from the 1970s to the latest models. Fans of vintage gaming will appreciate titles like The Addams Family, Black Knight, Twilight Zone, and the colossal Hercules machine, which holds the distinction of being the largest pinball machine ever made. The best part? You pay one admission fee and then play to your heart's content all day long. The museum even gives you a wristband that allows you to leave and return later, making it a flexible option for a day out in Chattanooga.

The museum’s approach to preserving the fun and science behind these machines has made it a beloved spot not just for hardcore gamers but also for families and casual visitors looking for a unique way to spend an afternoon. It’s a place where you can step back in time, away from today’s high-tech gaming, and enjoy the tactile and auditory satisfaction of a pinball hitting its mark.

Open every day except Monday, the museum offers extended hours on weekends, which are the busiest times. For a more relaxed experience, it's best to visit on a weekday or early in the day before the crowds arrive. The museum's popularity is evident from the consistently positive reviews it garners. Visitors often highlight the friendly atmosphere and the excellent condition of the machines, which are meticulously maintained.

The Chattanooga Pinball Museum also plays a positive role in the community, partnering with local charities like the Ronald McDonald House to raise funds through special events. This gives visitors another reason to feel good about spending time there.

Whether you're a pinball wizard or just looking to recapture some of that old-school arcade magic, the Chattanooga Pinball Museum provides an experience that’s both fun and refreshingly different from the usual tourist fare.

3.  International Towing & Recovery Museum

Location: 3315 Broad Street, Chattanooga, TN 37408

The International Towing & Recovery Museum, located on Broad Street in Chattanooga, is an unexpected gem that dives deep into the world of towing—a field that most people only think about when their car breaks down. Opened in 1995, this museum doesn’t just house old tow trucks; it tells the story of an industry that’s crucial to keeping roads safe and clear.

As soon as you step inside, you're greeted by a collection of over 24 meticulously restored tow trucks, some dating back to the early 1900s. One of the standout pieces is the 1913 Cadillac tow truck, the very first of its kind, invented by Ernest Holmes Sr. right here in Chattanooga. The museum does a fantastic job of taking visitors through the evolution of towing technology, showcasing how it has adapted to meet the demands of changing automotive landscapes over the decades.

The museum is also home to the Towing and Recovery Hall of Fame, which honors individuals who have made significant contributions to the industry. This adds a personal touch, giving faces and stories to the machines on display.

Another powerful element of the museum is the Wall of the Fallen, a memorial dedicated to tow operators who have lost their lives on the job. It’s a sobering reminder of the risks these workers take to help others, and it adds a depth of respect and reflection to the visit.

The museum is open from Tuesday through Sunday, and it's best to visit in the early morning or late afternoon to avoid the crowds. Visitors often describe the museum as unexpectedly engaging, even for those who aren't car enthusiasts. It’s well-curated, with clear, informative displays that make the history accessible to everyone.

In addition to the exhibits, the museum hosts events like the annual Hall of Fame induction ceremony, which draws visitors from across the country. The gift shop is worth a stop too, offering unique memorabilia that you won't find elsewhere.

Overall, the International Towing & Recovery Museum offers a rare look at a vital industry, shedding light on the history and people behind the trucks we often take for granted. It's a surprisingly compelling stop on any trip to Chattanooga.
Pinball captured in light and shadow

4.  Bessie Smith Cultural Center

Location: 200 East M.L. King Boulevard, Chattanooga, TN 37403

The Bessie Smith Cultural Center, located at 200 East M.L. King Boulevard in Chattanooga, is an important institution dedicated to preserving and celebrating African American history and culture in the region. Originally founded in 1983 as the Chattanooga African American Museum, it was later renamed in 2009 to honor the legendary blues singer Bessie Smith, who was born in Chattanooga and became known as the "Empress of the Blues."

The center plays a vital role in educating visitors about the contributions of African Americans to the development of Chattanooga and the broader American narrative. It offers a range of exhibits that cover various aspects of African American life, from the struggles and triumphs of the Civil Rights Movement to the rich cultural traditions that have shaped the community. The center also houses the Bessie Smith Performance Hall, a well-known venue for hosting performances, banquets, and community events.

The museum is open from Tuesday to Friday, 10:00 AM to 5:00 PM, and on Saturdays by appointment only. It is closed on Sundays and Mondays. Admission is $10 for adults, with discounted rates for seniors, students, and military personnel. Children under 5 can enter for free. The center is easily accessible, with free parking available in a nearby lot.

Visitors generally appreciate the depth and quality of the exhibits, though some note that the museum could benefit from more interactive elements. The center is usually not crowded, making it an excellent destination for those who prefer a quieter, more contemplative museum experience. The best times to visit are during the weekday mornings when the museum is less likely to be busy.

The Bessie Smith Cultural Center is not just a museum; it's a hub of cultural and educational activities that deepen the understanding of African American heritage in Chattanooga. Whether you’re a history enthusiast or simply curious about the local culture, the center offers valuable insights into a significant part of American history.

5.  Coker Museum

Location: 1309 Chestnut Street, Chattanooga, TN 37402

The Coker Museum in Chattanooga is a treasure trove for automotive enthusiasts, offering a deep dive into the world of vintage cars and motorcycles. Located at 1309 Chestnut Street, the museum is part of a historic complex that adds to its charm, housing over 130 classic vehicles, including cars, trucks, buses, motorcycles, and even airplanes.

What sets this museum apart is its vibrant, working atmosphere. It’s not just a place where old cars sit collecting dust; it's a living collection. The vehicles on display are part of Corky Coker's personal collection, assembled over decades and reflecting significant eras in automotive history. Visitors can explore everything from a rare 1909 Lozier Model J to a lineup of pristine European roadsters. The museum also features a working garage where restorations are constantly underway, providing a behind-the-scenes look at the meticulous work that goes into preserving these machines.

The museum is self-guided, allowing visitors to take their time exploring the collection. QR codes on the vehicles link to videos where Corky Coker shares insights and stories, adding a personal touch to the experience. The museum is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10:00 AM to 4:00 PM, with admission priced at $12 for adults and discounts available for seniors, military personnel, and children.

Visitors consistently praise the museum as a hidden gem in Chattanooga. The combination of the historic setting, the extensive collection, and the active restoration work makes it a compelling destination, whether you’re a car enthusiast or simply looking for something unique to do in the city. The museum tends to be quieter on weekdays, making those times ideal for a visit if you prefer a more relaxed experience.

In summary, the Coker Museum offers a rare glimpse into the world of vintage vehicles, presented in a way that’s both informative and engaging. It’s a must-visit for anyone interested in automotive history or looking to experience a piece of Chattanooga’s industrial heritage.

6.  Lodge Museum of Cast Iron

Location: 220 East 3rd Street, South Pittsburg, TN 37380

The Lodge Museum of Cast Iron in South Pittsburg, Tennessee, offers a deep dive into the history and cultural significance of cast iron cookware, particularly the iconic Lodge brand. Opened in 2022, this museum provides an engaging experience for anyone interested in cooking, manufacturing, or American history.

Visitors are greeted by interactive exhibits that walk them through the entire process of making cast iron cookware—from raw materials to finished products. The museum doesn’t just stop at the technical aspects; it also explores the evolution of Lodge Cast Iron, a company that has been a staple in American kitchens since 1896. Displays highlight key moments in the company’s history, such as its survival through the Great Depression and its innovation of pre-seasoned cookware in the early 2000s.

A major attraction is the world’s largest cast iron skillet, which weighs a staggering 14,360 pounds. It’s a piece of Americana that draws a lot of attention and makes for a memorable photo opportunity.

Open daily from 8:00 AM to 6:00 PM Central Time, the museum is well-suited for a quick stop or a longer, more detailed visit. Admission is $10, and children under 5 get in free. Most people spend about an hour exploring the museum, but plan for additional time if you want to shop at the adjacent Factory Store or enjoy a meal at Big Bad Breakfast, the on-site restaurant.

Visitors generally rave about the museum’s well-organized exhibits and the informative, hands-on experiences that make it enjoyable for all ages. Whether you’re a cast iron enthusiast or simply curious about the history of this ubiquitous cookware, the Lodge Museum of Cast Iron offers a unique and informative outing.

7.  Chickamauga Battlefield Visitor Center

Location: 3370 LaFayette Road, Fort Oglethorpe, GA 30742

The Chickamauga Battlefield Visitor Center in Fort Oglethorpe, Georgia, is an essential stop for anyone interested in American history, particularly the Civil War. As part of the Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park, the center offers a deep dive into one of the war’s most significant battles. The Battle of Chickamauga, fought in September 1863, was among the bloodiest conflicts of the Civil War, and the visitor center provides a comprehensive look at the events that unfolded here.

Upon entering, visitors are greeted by exhibits that lay out the context and key moments of the battle. The displays include dioramas, informational panels, and an impressive lighted map presentation that helps visitors visualize the battle strategies. For those with a particular interest in military history, the Fuller Gun Collection is a notable feature, showcasing an extensive array of muskets and rifles from various periods. However, it’s worth noting that the collection might appeal more to dedicated enthusiasts, as the exhibit includes minimal explanatory text.

The center also offers a well-produced orientation film, "The Campaign for Chattanooga: Death Knell of the Confederacy," which plays every half-hour. The film provides a gripping overview of the battles that took place in the area, though its graphic nature might not be suitable for very young children.

The grounds surrounding the visitor center are equally compelling. With 50 miles of hiking trails, 22 miles of biking trails, and 256 cannons scattered across the battlefield, there’s ample opportunity to explore and reflect on the historical significance of the site. Many visitors recommend the self-guided auto tour, which spans about 8 miles and covers key points of interest. There’s also a cell phone tour option that offers audio commentary at various stops, making it easier to understand the battlefield’s history as you go.

Crowds tend to be lighter in the early morning and late afternoon, so these are the best times to visit if you’re looking for a quieter experience. The visitor center is open daily from 8:30 AM to 5:00 PM, and the battlefield itself is open from dawn to dusk.

Visitor reviews are overwhelmingly positive, with many people noting the emotional impact of walking the grounds where so many lives were lost. The exhibits and the battlefield combine to create a powerful, reflective experience that brings the history of the Civil War to life in a deeply personal way.

8.  Creative Discovery Museum

Location: 321 Chestnut Street, Chattanooga, TN 37402

The Creative Discovery Museum in Chattanooga is a cornerstone for families and young explorers, offering a space where learning and play merge seamlessly. Since opening in 1995, this hands-on museum has been dedicated to sparking curiosity and creativity in children. Located at 321 Chestnut Street in the heart of downtown Chattanooga, it has become a beloved destination for both locals and visitors seeking an engaging and educational experience.

The museum is designed for children aged 18 months to 12 years, featuring a wide range of exhibits that cater to various interests. From the RiverPlay water-themed zone, where kids can explore the mechanics of locks and dams, to the Inventor’s Workshop that encourages tinkering and innovation, there’s something for every young mind to explore. The rooftop area, often overlooked by visitors, offers additional hands-on activities and provides a great view of downtown Chattanooga.

The Creative Discovery Museum isn’t just about individual exploration. It regularly hosts events and workshops, which are popular among families looking to enrich their children's learning experiences. Whether it’s a themed event tied to a temporary exhibit or a special workshop in the ArtSpace or STEM Zone, there’s always something new and exciting happening.

Operating hours are consistent, with the museum open daily from 10:00 AM to 5:00 PM. Admission is $16.95 for general entry if purchased online, slightly higher at the door, and $13.95 for seniors. Membership options are available, offering free admission and other benefits for regular visitors. Given its popularity, especially on weekends and holidays, it’s wise to buy tickets in advance to avoid disappointment.

Visitor reviews consistently praise the museum for its interactive exhibits and the way it captivates children while also educating them. Some visitors note that the museum can get quite busy, especially during peak times, so those looking for a quieter experience might prefer visiting on a weekday morning.

In summary, the Creative Discovery Museum offers a dynamic environment where children can learn, create, and play in a setting designed to nurture their curiosity. Whether you’re a local or just passing through Chattanooga, it’s a must-visit destination for families.

9.  Charles H. Coolidge National Medal of Honor Heritage Center

Location: 2 West Aquarium Way, Chattanooga, TN 37402

The Charles H. Coolidge National Medal of Honor Heritage Center, located at 2 West Aquarium Way in Chattanooga, Tennessee, is a significant institution that honors the bravery and sacrifices of Medal of Honor recipients. Opened in February 2020, this 19,500-square-foot facility is dedicated to preserving and sharing the stories of the courageous individuals who have received the United States' highest military honor.

The Heritage Center is named after Charles H. Coolidge, a World War II veteran and Medal of Honor recipient known for his extraordinary bravery during combat in France. The center's mission is not only to memorialize these heroic actions but also to educate future generations about the core values exemplified by these recipients: Patriotism, Citizenship, Courage, Integrity, Sacrifice, and Commitment.

Visitors to the center can explore life-sized, immersive exhibits that bring these stories to life, providing a profound understanding of what it means to earn the Medal of Honor. The exhibits cover the history of the Medal of Honor from its inception during the Civil War to the present day, making it both a historical and educational experience.

The Heritage Center is open Thursday through Saturday from 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM and on Sundays from 10:00 AM to 3:30 PM. The last tickets are sold 45 minutes before closing. Admission fees are reasonable, with discounts available for seniors, students, and military personnel.

Reviews often highlight the emotional impact of the exhibits, noting how the center effectively conveys the gravity of the sacrifices made by Medal of Honor recipients. Visitors appreciate the detailed presentations and the respectful, solemn atmosphere of the center. Crowds tend to be lighter on weekday mornings, making this an ideal time to visit if you prefer a more reflective experience.

Overall, the Charles H. Coolidge National Medal of Honor Heritage Center provides a powerful and moving tribute to American heroes and is a must-visit for those interested in military history or the values that define true heroism.
The search for Bigfoot

10.  EXPEDITION: BIGFOOT! The Sasquatch Museum

Location: 1934 Highway 515, Cherry Log, GA 30513

EXPEDITION: BIGFOOT! The Sasquatch Museum in Cherry Log, Georgia (about 1.5 hours from Chattanooga), offers a fascinating experience for anyone curious about the legend of Bigfoot. This 3,700-square-foot museum, opened in 2016, is the largest of its kind in the world, housing an extensive collection of artifacts, exhibits, and research related to Bigfoot and other cryptids.

The museum was founded by David Bakara, a dedicated Bigfoot enthusiast whose lifelong interest in the creature is evident in the care and detail of the exhibits. Visitors can explore a range of displays, including life-sized models, footprint casts, and an impressive collection of Bigfoot-related memorabilia. One of the standout features is the "Sasquatch Theater," where a short film delves into the global phenomenon of Bigfoot-like creatures, from the Yeti of the Himalayas to the Skunk Ape of Florida.

The exhibits blend cultural history with modern-day sightings and research, making the museum both educational and entertaining. You’ll find detailed maps marking reported sightings, Native American artifacts that tie into the Bigfoot legend, and even the world’s only Bigfoot Research and Tech Vehicle. Whether you're a believer or a skeptic, the museum offers a comprehensive look at the Bigfoot phenomenon that is sure to spark curiosity.

Open daily from 10:00 AM to 5:00 PM, the museum is a convenient stop for those traveling through the North Georgia mountains. Admission is affordable, with tickets priced at $8 for adults and $6 for children aged 5-12. The museum is family-friendly, with strollers allowed and diaper-changing stations available, and it’s mostly accessible for visitors with disabilities. However, it’s worth noting that pets are not permitted inside, though a free kennel service is available on the porch.

Visitor reviews often highlight the museum’s balance of education and entertainment. It's a great stop for families, with interactive exhibits that engage visitors of all ages. The museum can be toured in about an hour, but those with a deeper interest might spend several hours exploring the extensive displays.

Located at 1934 Highway 515, Cherry Log, Georgia, EXPEDITION: BIGFOOT! is a must-visit for anyone intrigued by the mystery of Bigfoot, offering a thorough and engaging look at one of the most enduring legends of the modern age.

Exploring Chattanooga and its surrounding areas offers an opportunity to connect with a rich and diverse array of cultural, historical, and even mythical stories. Each of these museums and cultural centers tells a unique story, from the heroism commemorated at the Charles H. Coolidge National Medal of Honor Heritage Center to the mysterious allure of Bigfoot at EXPEDITION: BIGFOOT!. These destinations go beyond simple exhibitions; they invite you to engage with the past, explore new ideas, and experience the depth of human creativity and resilience. Whether you're delving into the African American heritage at the Bessie Smith Cultural Center or marveling at vintage cars at the Coker Museum, each visit provides a new perspective on the world and its history.

Chattanooga's museums are not just places to observe—they are spaces to interact, learn, and reflect. They offer a chance to understand the local culture and broader historical narratives through carefully curated exhibits that speak to all ages. Whether you're planning a day trip, a weekend getaway, or a deeper exploration of the region, these museums provide the perfect itinerary for anyone seeking to enrich their understanding of history, culture, and the natural world.

This farm was founded in 1998 and now its a bastion of the Chattanooga community.

There is also a seasonal farm stand that runs from April to November, which opens on Fridays and Saturdays at 10am-3pm providing fresh produce, herbs, flowers as well co-op items.

Most of you are familiar with the big events at Crabtree Farms, like our Spring and Fall Plant Sales. Food talks will also be complemented by educational workshops offering experience in sustainable gardening, canning and more.

A fully stocked gift shop, selling a variety of Mayfield branded products are also available- when you drop by, be sure to check out abeautiful memento. From 10 AM to 5 PM (with tours from 10 AM to 3 PM), the facility is open Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday. A reminder: Closed to the public on Saturdays (No Tours) but our gift shop and Ice Cream Parlor will be open 9am-2pm. Please be advised that the center is closed on Wednesdays and Sundays.

4.  Apple Valley Orchard

Location: 351 Weese Road SE, Cleveland, TN 37323

At Apple Valley Orchard in Cleveland, TN you will find not just an orchard but a historical landmark that has provided generations of local with the iconic chunk of Tennessee farm life. This hobby farm has grown to 40 acres of land, and over the years we have found space for more than 15,000 apple trees. The result: It quickly transformed into a must-visit for those locals and visitors craving fresh apple pie or other baked treats, not to mention the quiet kind of charm you can only find in rural American locations.

Apple Valley Orchard makes for a great location to bring the family, particularly if you have little ones! Its a year round orchard that is very popular during harvest season where you can pick your own apples which starts in the middle of july and goes on to Fall. This period is when the orchard extends its hours to cater for large numbers of visitors coming out to pick delicious apples and devouring seasonal delights from their bakery.

Its bakery is especially noteworthy, serving apple cider and fried apple pies (among other tasty treats). These are the items receiving rave reviews with Southern Living Magazine naming their fried apple pies one of the best in America. The orchard also sells fresh apple cider, slushies and many flavors of jams & jellies from their crops as well.

Apple Valley Orchard is perfect for young families. Kids can be Kids here while learning about apple farming, the process of making cider and riding through the bulked-lined rows on wagons pulled by a tractor. You can ride them on weekends throughout the peak fall season (already under way, but available through Oct. 28) for a little extra seasonal fun.

Best time to go: Visit the orchard during apple harvest in September and October, on weekends for a farm experience. We recommend coming early, especially on weekends when the orchard can get rather busy with families and apple aficionados. That can be especially true in the packed tractor rides.

5.  Lucky Ladd Farms

Location: 4374 Rocky Glade Road, Eagleville, TN 37060

Lucky Ladd Farms is one of the most memorable family destinations in Middle Tennessee featuring a unique blend of farming and fun with dozens of hands-on activities - excitement for all ages! This barnyard includes 60 acres of land and is considered by many to be the largest petting farm in TN – it boasts itself as one of Nashville's top destinations for family fun.

Those who visit Lucky Ladd Farms will find a plethora of activities beyond the typical farm experience. The petting farm is a favourite, where kids and adults can meet more than 100 animals from familiar farm types to some exotic beasts. Besides the animals, it also has mansion slides, a wagon ride down to another farm with pony rides and a splash pad making it an experience for all!

Those interested in a more educational visit will find exhibits and nature trails detailing farm life as well the natural world. The farm also offers seasonal attractions: pumpkin patch in the fall, flower-picking events in spring.

Lucky Ladd FarmsYulefest excels in being an event that is family-friendly, especially for those with younger children. The farm is laid out for fun AND safety so lots and LOTS of room to roam. With loads of playgrounds and adventure areas to burn off excitement, the educational exhibits make for a good chance to learn practically.

Relying on seasonal business, Lucky Ladd Farms closes through the winter months but can draw upwards of 30K visitors from when they reopen in April for their Spring Season up until Halloween is over. Located at 4374 Rocky Glade Road in Eagleville, Tennessee, the farm is located close to Nashville so it makes for a great day trip for families travelling through.

Families that visit Lucky Ladd Farms rave about all the fun things to do and what a wholesome place it is. Animal encounters are particularly popular with children, and the seasonal events mentioned regularly as best bits. Still, some people have complained of accessibility and a lackluster customer service experience for those with mobility limitations.
Two cows stand peacefully in a wide-open pasture

6.  Bird Fork Farm

Location: Near Dunlap, TN (Cumberland Plateau)

Nestled in Chattanooga, TN, Bird Fork Farm also deserves to be highlighted as a visionary endeavor that exemplifies holistic approaches towards sustainable and regenerative agriculture. Nestled on 55 acres of hillside in the rolling hills of Tennessee's Cumberland Plateau, this woman-run farm has become renowned for its incredible produce—a wonderful selection grown with zero pesticides and clearly a genuine heart-centered connection to ecology.

Bird Fork Farm puts their heart and soul into raising clean food, not trying to participate in agritourism like many typical farms. A Certified Naturally Grown farm, which is recognized by the U. S. Department of Agriculture, but also has standards stricter than those of organic certification Permaculture practices inform the growth of an expansive orchard containing literally tons of fruits and vegetables including: apples, pears, garlic scapes; herbs such as sage and cilantro — all on a variety plot that keeps yields high while keeping soils healthy for generations to come.

Bird Fork Farm sells its products at a variety of farmers markets in the area, including Main Street Farmers Market in Chattanooga. Hipcamp also has camping options for those who want to visit the farm in person, which will provide a much more “in-the-weeds” experience. Guests are welcome to camp at several scenic sites on the farm, including open pastures and wooded areas, while participating in everything from hiking trails to checking out some of the nearby state parks.

While Bird Fork Farm doesn't have playgrounds or petting zoos, its appeal to families looking for nature is less overt. Its educational component is what attracts many to the farm, particularly families looking for ways of including children in food origins and sustainable farming. Kids can go wild in the open spaces, smile at plants or get behind upcoming workshops that focus on everything natural.

One of the few times to interact with Bird Fork Farm is at a farmers' market where they sell their produce. Chattanooga — Main Street Farmers Market (year-round market, Wednesday from 4 to 6 PM) The lush landscape makes for a great setting to have Ontario agri-tourism experience within an easy, scenic drive: + During the warmer months visitors may CAMP right on the farm (just mellows that small part with electricity and some roughing it needed).

The response burden by their trusted customers is a testament to the farm's dedication to sustainability and product quality. Overall, the place has received rave reviews from campers who have stayed on the farm through Hipcamp for its peaceful setting and nearness to things people would do outdoors—all perfect criteria when getting away from urban life.

7.  Copper Creek Farm

Location: 1514 Reeves Station Rd SW, Calhoun, GA 30701

Copper Creek Farm in Calhoun, GA is a family-friendly destination for guests of all ages to enjoy. At the base of the Appalachians, this farm in North Georgia is dedicated to combining traditional farming with new-age entertainment; and for that alone it stands out.

Copper Creek Farm is well known for their seasonal events, bringing people from all over the Southeast. The farm's Park Calendar is filled with activities for all ages and interests so it remains an attraction throughout the year. The Sunflower Festival is another popular outdoor event that happens across Brooklyn in summer, allowing visitors to see the rows and rolls of bright golden petals through photography or just recreational activities. But as the leaves change, it becomes a fall wonderland with its massive corn maze, pumpkin patch and family activities such as pig races and gem mining.

Copper Creek Farm — open seasonally, based on events The Sunflower Festival in the summer and fall harvests when the farm is hopping with activities are good times of year to visit. But get there early, because it can be very crowded on the weekends. Parking is free of charge but gets so bad later in the day that it's best to go very early.

Copper Creek Farm is noted for being especially family-friendly with Park-wide appeal. Activities at the farm are made for children and adults, allowing families to spend a day together. These attractions are perfect for even the youngest visitors, providing hillbilly splash pad pony rides and more. The farm now has a General Store, which makes for an adorable shopping experience —albeit very short— where guests can purchase wonderful local products such as glazed pecans, goat soap and honey available depending on seasonal availablity and time of year.

Copper Creek Farm is open seasonally, aligning its operating hours with its major events. The best times to visit are during the Sunflower Festival in the summer and the fall harvest season when the farm is in full swing with activities. However, visitors should plan ahead, as the farm can get quite busy, especially on weekends. It’s advisable to arrive early to avoid traffic and secure good parking.

Reviews from past visitors often highlight the variety of activities and the overall enjoyment of the experience. However, some have noted that traffic and parking can be an issue during peak times, so planning your visit carefully is recommended.

Copper Creek Farm is an experience, not just a farm. Thanks to its seasonal events, broad range of activities and family-friendly feel the farm attracts families in their droves for a day out on the rural fringes. Whether you are tromping through sunflower fields, trekking a corn maze or just wanting the perfect picnic day with your family, Copper Creek Farm gives everyone what they need to make their visit well-rounded and fun.

With some of the farms so close to Chattanooga; it's not only a nice change up from your regular routine, but an opportunity to get in touch with the land and our communities, build relationships with those who grow or cook what we eat on a daily basis. Stroll through Crabtree Farms and witness the influence of urban agriculture combine with sustainable farming as you join in community-driven gatherings that unite people. On the other hand, Hidden Hills Farm & Saddle Club offers visitors a first-hand glimpse into country life: horseback riding (or pony rides), kids' farm play days or just taking in beautiful views of rolling countryside. But, more than destinations to experience here and now; these are the farms on which you can create lasting memories with friends and family, gain a hands-on agricultural education or simply lift up your community. Whether you are local to the area or just passing through, definitely check out these farms and see why they add such value to Chattanooga as a whole.

title: 6 of the Best Bites on Wheels in Chattanooga
body:
Food truck parked at a local park
Chattanooga is a culinary treasure trove, particularly for food lovers eager to explore a diverse range of food trucks. The city boasts an array of mobile eateries, each offering unique and delectable dishes that cater to every palate. Whether you're a seasoned food truck enthusiast or a curious foodie, Chattanooga's vibrant food truck scene promises a variety of cuisines and experiences that are sure to delight. From savory empanadas to smoky barbecue, these food trucks are not only a testament to culinary creativity but also a reflection of the city’s rich cultural tapestry. Many of these businesses also offer catering services, making them perfect for events and gatherings. If we missed one of your favorite trucks, please reach out, and we'll be sure to add it to our list. Join us as we embark on a delicious journey through Chattanooga's bustling food truck landscape, where every stop offers a new and exciting flavor adventure.

1.  California Smothered Burrito - Chattanooga, TN

Chattanooga’s vibrant food scene gets a delightful infusion of West Coast flair with the California Smothered Burrito food truck. Known for its hearty, flavor-packed burritos and friendly service, this mobile eatery has quickly become a favorite among locals and visitors alike.

California Smothered Burrito has carved out a niche in Chattanooga by delivering authentic California-style burritos. The food truck, adorned with a vintage aesthetic and a surfboard on top, exudes a laid-back vibe that complements its culinary offerings perfectly. Frequenting locations across the city, from bustling farmers markets to lively music festivals, this food truck brings the taste of the West Coast to the heart of Tennessee.

The menu at California Smothered Burrito is both diverse and indulgent, offering something for everyone:
  • Smothered Burrito: A crowd favorite, this burrito is packed with your choice of chicken, beef, or vegetarian fillings, black beans, rice, and a plethora of fresh toppings, all smothered in white queso and green chili. It’s served with a side of chips and salsa.
  • Chicken Enchilada Burrito: Another popular choice, this burrito features tender chicken, rice, sour cream, and enchilada sauce, topped with queso and black olives.
  • Ultimate Nachos: A must-try, these nachos are loaded with all the burrito ingredients and covered in white queso, offering a perfect blend of flavors and textures.
  • Malibu Wrap: For a lighter option, the Malibu Wrap combines chicken, avocado, lettuce, and tomato with ranch dressing, all wrapped in a soft tortilla.

Unlike traditional brick-and-mortar establishments, California Smothered Burrito is constantly on the move. The truck operates at various locations throughout Chattanooga, including popular spots like the Chattanooga Market and local events. To find out where they’ll be next, following their social media pages on Facebook and Instagram is essential.

Crowd Tips and Best Times to Visit: Given its popularity, California Smothered Burrito often attracts sizable crowds, especially during festivals and weekend markets. For those looking to avoid long waits, visiting during weekdays or following their social media updates for less crowded spots is advisable.

Patrons consistently praise the truck for its generous portions and flavorful offerings. One reviewer raved about the “smothered burrito with green chili,” highlighting the perfect blend of ingredients and the fresh, made-to-order quality. Another lauded the “Ultimate Nachos,” describing them as a delectable and must-try item. The friendly service and vibrant atmosphere further enhance the dining experience.

California Smothered Burrito brings a slice of the West Coast to Chattanooga, offering a unique and flavorful dining experience on wheels. Whether you’re a burrito aficionado or just looking to try something new, this food truck promises a satisfying meal that’s well worth tracking down. For more information, visit their official website.

2.  Rolling J's Mobile Bistro - Chattanooga, TN

In the bustling culinary landscape of Chattanooga, Rolling J's Mobile Bistro stands out as a beacon of Southern gourmet delight. Located at 804 Riverfront Parkway, Suite 126, this family-owned food truck and sandwich shop has been serving up a delectable mix of Southern classics and innovative dishes since 2013. Known for its high-quality ingredients and exceptional service, Rolling J's has garnered a loyal following among locals and visitors alike.

Rolling J's Mobile Bistro brings the comfort of Southern home cooking to the streets of Chattanooga with a touch of gourmet flair. The food truck's emphasis on fresh, locally sourced ingredients and its commitment to quality shine through in every dish. The truck itself is a familiar sight at local events, markets, and festivals, easily recognizable with its inviting setup and friendly staff.

The menu at Rolling J's Mobile Bistro offers a delightful array of options that cater to diverse palates. Signature items include:
  • Smoked Brisket: Tender and flavorful, served with cider slaw, grilled asparagus, and mashed potatoes.
  • Pulled Pork: A Southern staple, paired with traditional slaw and creamy baked mac & cheese.
  • Special Sauce Sandwiches: Known for their distinct and delicious flavors, these sandwiches are a must-try.
  • Ch'talian Sandwich: Exclusive to their brick-and-mortar shop, this sandwich features fire smoked ham, pepperoni, Genoa salami, and muenster cheese on local sourdough, making it a hit among patrons.

Rolling J's Mobile Bistro operates from Monday to Saturday, 11:00 AM to 3:00 PM. However, as a food truck, its location can vary. The best way to keep track of its whereabouts and operating hours is by following their social media pages on Facebook and Instagram.

What the Customers Say: Rolling J's has received glowing reviews for both its food and service. One reviewer praised the “perfectly smoked brisket and tangy slaw,” highlighting the truck’s mastery of Southern BBQ flavors. Another customer raved about the “fantastic banana pudding,” a signature dessert that sets Rolling J's apart from other food trucks in the area. The truck is also well-regarded for its involvement in community and charity events, further endearing it to the Chattanooga community.

  • Best Times to Visit: Weekdays are generally less crowded, making it a good time to enjoy a leisurely meal without the wait.
  • Stay Updated: Keep an eye on their social media for real-time updates on locations and menu specials.
  • Catering Services: Consider Rolling J's for your next event. They offer catering with customizable menus to suit any occasion, ensuring a memorable dining experience for your guests.

In conclusion, Rolling J's Mobile Bistro is a must-visit for anyone seeking an authentic taste of Southern gourmet cuisine in Chattanooga. Whether you're a local or just passing through, this food truck promises a meal that's both satisfying and memorable. For more information, visit their official website.

3.  Tacos El Tote - Chattanooga, TN

Located at 5601 St Elmo Avenue, Chattanooga, Tacos El Tote is a vibrant food truck that has captured the hearts and taste buds of locals and visitors alike. Renowned for its authentic Mexican cuisine, this culinary hotspot offers a delightful blend of traditional flavors and fresh ingredients, making it a must-visit for anyone craving a taste of Mexico.

Tacos El Tote has established itself as a staple in Chattanooga’s food scene, bringing the rich and diverse flavors of Mexico to the streets. The food truck’s bright and inviting exterior is matched by the warm and friendly service provided by the staff, creating a welcoming atmosphere that keeps customers coming back for more.

The menu at Tacos El Tote is a testament to the culinary traditions of Mexico, featuring a variety of dishes that cater to different tastes and preferences. Some of the standout items include:
  • Quesabirria Tacos: These tacos are a fan favorite, filled with succulent birria meat and melted mozzarella cheese, and served with a side of savory birria broth for dipping. The combination of flavors is simply irresistible.
  • Pastor Tacos: Seasoned pork tacos that offer a perfect balance of spice and flavor, making them a staple for taco enthusiasts.
  • Breakfast Burritos: A hearty option to kickstart your day, these burritos are packed with a variety of delicious fillings.
  • Chopped Steak: A flavorful choice that meat lovers will appreciate, cooked to perfection and bursting with taste.
  • Burrito Bowls: For those seeking a lighter option, the burrito bowls provide all the deliciousness without the tortilla.
  • Chorizo Tacos and Quesadillas: Spicy and savory, these items are sure to satisfy your cravings.
  • Street Corn: Often praised by customers, this side dish is a must-try, offering a delightful mix of sweet and savory flavors.

Tacos El Tote operates from Monday to Friday, 8:00 AM to 8:00 PM, and is closed on weekends. Given its popularity, the food truck can get quite busy, especially during peak hours. To avoid long waits, it’s advisable to visit during off-peak times.

The reviews for Tacos El Tote are overwhelmingly positive, with many customers lauding the quality of the food and the exceptional service. One reviewer highlighted the “quality Birria, like literally the best street corn,” while another mentioned the “delicious and savory veggie burrito bowl.” The consistent praise from patrons underscores the food truck’s commitment to delivering an authentic and enjoyable dining experience.

Tacos El Tote offers a slice of Mexico in the heart of Chattanooga, combining authentic flavors with a friendly atmosphere. Whether you’re a local or just passing through, this food truck is a must-visit destination for anyone looking to indulge in high-quality Mexican cuisine. For more information and the latest updates on their location and hours, follow Tacos El Tote on their Facebook and Instagram pages.
Food truck serving lunch to locals

4.  Mama Yo's Soul Food - Chattanooga, TN

Located at 3701 Alton Park Blvd, Chattanooga, TN, Mama Yo's Soul Food is a cherished food truck that has earned a reputation for its hearty and delicious soul food. Known for serving up home-cooked meals that evoke the warmth and comfort of traditional Southern cuisine, Mama Yo's has become a favorite among locals and visitors alike.

Mama Yo's Soul Food offers a welcoming experience that embodies the essence of Southern hospitality. The food truck’s menu is a rich assortment of soul food classics, each dish meticulously prepared to deliver an authentic taste of the South.

The menu at Mama Yo's Soul Food is filled with soul food staples that have garnered rave reviews from its patrons. Some standout items include:
  • BBQ Chicken: Juicy, tender, and perfectly seasoned.
  • Pulled Pork: Slow-cooked to perfection, this dish is flavorful and often described as melt-in-your-mouth.
  • Whiting Fish: Crispy on the outside and tender on the inside.
  • Chicken and Dressing: A comforting and traditional Southern dish.
  • Collard Greens, Mac and Cheese, Turnip Greens, and Baked Beans: These sides are bursting with flavor and cooked to perfection.

Mama Yo's operates from Monday to Thursday, 12:00 PM to 7:00 PM, extending its hours on Friday and Saturday until 8:00 PM, and on Sunday from 12:00 PM to 7:00 PM. To avoid the crowds and enjoy a more relaxed experience, visiting during weekday lunchtimes is recommended.

The reviews for Mama Yo's Soul Food are overwhelmingly positive. Customers frequently praise the generous portions and exceptional flavor. One diner remarked, "The plates are huge, enough for me to have two meals. The food is beyond amazing!" Another highlighted the pulled pork sandwich as the best they’ve had in Chattanooga, perfectly sauced with a little slaw. The ribs and steaming hot, made-to-order French fries also come highly recommended.

Mama Yo's Soul Food truck offers a dining experience that is both nostalgic and delicious, providing a true taste of Southern cuisine. Whether you're a local or just passing through Chattanooga, this food truck is a must-visit for anyone looking to indulge in authentic soul food. For the latest updates on their location and hours, follow Mama Yo's on their Facebook page.

5.  Chatter Box Cafe - Chattanooga, TN

Located at 6801 Shallowford Rd, Chattanooga, TN, Chatter Box Cafe has become a favorite destination for barbecue enthusiasts. This food truck and restaurant, known for its exceptional smoked meats and Southern hospitality, delivers a dining experience that keeps patrons returning for more.

Chatter Box Cafe excels with its authentic barbecue offerings, meticulously prepared to perfection. The food truck, under the expert hands of Chef Brandon, emphasizes low and slow cooking methods to ensure that each bite is tender and flavorful. The inviting atmosphere and warm service enhance the overall experience, making diners feel right at home.

The menu at Chatter Box Cafe is a celebration of Southern barbecue, featuring an array of smoked and barbecue dishes that cater to diverse tastes. Some of the standout items include:
  • Smoked Mac N Cheese: This dish elevates the classic comfort food with a rich, smoky flavor.
  • Brisket Sandwich: A generous portion of tender brisket served on a soft bun, praised for its depth of flavor.
  • Brisket and Ribs: A duo of barbecue favorites, both slow-cooked to achieve a perfect balance of smokiness and tenderness.
  • Smoked Chicken: Juicy and flavorful, this dish highlights the expert smoking techniques used at Chatter Box.
  • Chicken Wings: These wings are a crowd favorite, known for their perfect seasoning and smoky finish.
  • BBQ Nachos: A creative twist on nachos, topped with pulled pork, cheese, and barbecue sauce.
  • Pulled Pork Plates: Accompanied by classic Southern sides like mac and cheese and fried okra, these plates offer a hearty meal that satisfies.
